description:
Basik is the best acai in the city, if not the world. I used to live walking distance and came almost every weekend. Now I live across the city and will literally still take a 45 minute muni or $10 uber just to get a bowl. Is that a little much? Probably. But I love Basik that much.

I am a creature of habit and like things simple, so I get the same thing every time- the Brazilian bowl. Their granola is the best and I always ask for extra to make sure the acai to granola ratio is on point. Recommended!

My only complaint is that the line moves slowly and it feels like they should be able to be more efficient back there, but it's honestly so good that I'm willing to wait.
author: Lindsey S.

description:
There is not better açaí bowls in the whole city than this ones! 
The service is great, all the staff is super friendly and you can even bring your dog! 
During weekends the line is long because they are super busy! 
They close early so don't ever be late... sometimes they close like 3 minutes before the actual hours so just go early than that.

My favorite bowl is the Puna with extra cacao nibs.
author: Daniela T.

description:
Got a hula lulu from Honolulu, that rock-a-hula baby of mine...Elvis has left the building. I like açaí bowls as much as the next guy, but this Hawaiian-based chain has taken it to a level of heavily sweetened excess. Now I suppose I could have ordered the $8 Brasilian, which is their basic blend of açaí and apple juice, topped with honey, granola, and bananas. In hindsight, that sounds pretty good, but hey, if this cafe is saying aloha to me, then I felt the need to order the $11 Islander, which blended açaí with hemp mylk (...yes, they spell it 'mylk' so I won't think it came from a cow). Toppings were kinda on the manic side...

Not only was there granola, bananas, and honey but also strawberries, gojiberries, and coconut shavings. Wow, look at this monstrosity with the honey dripping over the side (photo: http://bit.ly/2M3GizB). It was frankly too sweet for my taste, and I couldn't finish it. The other choices appeared just as elaborate with toppings like bee pollen, cacao nibs, and hemp hearts in the mix. The smoothies sound like they'd go down easier assuming they are fully blended. There wasn't much in the way of festive decor in here - no ukuleles, no welcome leis, no voodoo-cursed tiki dolls. All the tropical decor will be in your stomach...at least temporarily.

FOOD - 3 stars...açaí bowls with a lotta bells & whistles
AMBIANCE - 2.5 stars...no Hawaiiana in here, pretty spartan
SERVICE - 2 stars...unsmiling like they've already OD'ed on the açaí 
TOTAL - 3 stars...if you want an açaí bowl with all the fixings and then some

RELATED - Looking for something Hawaiian for dinner? Here's a list of places I've tried and reviewed: http://bit.ly/2w7kFIu
author: Ed U.

description: I really like this place but find it annoying that they charge extra to substitute agave for honey...I understand charging extra for additional items, but charging to substitute one sweetener for another seems silly to me.
author: Christina M.

description:
A great place if you're vegan, they use a lot of milk alternatives like cashew milk and cacao nibs, and you can easily ask for no honey. However, a little overpriced, even for açaí bowls. If you get the large ($14) and split it between two people it becomes an average SF price, but paying ~$11 for a small (1/2 to 1/3 of the size) is definitely not worth. I do like that you can customize the bowl, like swapping out granola or different types of milk. Of course, this also costs extra.

But overall, the price warrants the experience and service. The space itself or gorgeous, lots of large, tall windows and an super high ceilings. Our bowl came out in under ten minutes, which was impressive considering there were a decent amount of customers in the store and only 2-3 workers!
author: Rachel L.

description:
Basik Cafe serves up good acai bowls albeit on the pricier side. You also get smaller portions for what you pay for, but the quality is what we're going for here. If you go here, you are to embrace your inner basic hoe (you thought the Basik in Basik Cafe meant something else?). Cute interiors and cute portions make for a basic picture if you catch the right angles and lighting.

Brasilian is their classic acai bowl with all the typical toppings. If you want to keep it simple, get the Brasilian. If bowls aren't your thing, they also serve smoothies! The cafe is pretty small but most people come and go, not staying to eat. And as per any SF establishment, parking is strictly street parking.
author: Derek T.

description:
Fave acai place in SF, but it's definitely on the pricier side. 

I got the forager, and my only regret is getting the small size instead of the large size. I like the consistency and texture of their acai!

There's not much seating inside, but people come and go, so hopefully there's not a long wait.

(Sad, Yelp didn't connect my photo with my review. Welps.)
author: Tiffany H.

description: GIVES ME ALL THE BEACH VIBES. SO GOOD. It is pricey and I mean very pricey but definitely WORTH it. Not a lot of space to sit but I'm down for this no matter what.
author: Veronica L.

description: Jumped into the açaí bowl boat three years ago. I regret not coming here sooner. The large Brazilian (spelling?) bowl is HUGEEEE and definitely worth the price. I typically come here and have that big bowl of açaí before the gym. It gives an extra pep to my step. It's a pretty small, but comfy place to just take a breather and read while you blindly shove açaí in your face.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
Basik is hands down the best acai bowl in SF for all points--portion size, quality of product, and price in San Francisco.

As a bougie acai lover trained in San Diego, I know I have unrealistically-high standards for my bowls. However, Basik holds it down! I ordered the Puna Bowl to go since my boo dropped me off to take the order. There is only street parking, and even then it's kind of difficult to find it on this busy street...so I'd recommend using public transport or Lyft to drop you off. I chose the Puna because of the spirulina and the lack of nuts #allergyyelper ALSO, can we all say a hip hip hooray for them using hemp milk instead of solely nut milk!? THANK YOU. Now to find an acai spot that does oat milk...hmm

I went with the largest size because we were sharing it, and both wanted a refreshing and light "pick me up" for lunch. The bowl was made within 8 minutes or so, very fast! The acai itself is the quality that I always judge hard. Basik's is more on the slushy side in terms of mouthfeel, but the taste is so flavorful and NOT overdone with extra ice or any of that extra crap. The flavors of the Puna bowl are so good and balanced. It was so delicious with the blueberries and YUMMY crunchy granola (nut-free for my allergy folks! however, they did preface my question with the "traces of nuts" component). We were able to finish the whole bowl without it melting in the car, while the sun was shining and heating up the bowl.

Their storefront is quite small in space, with a few high top tables and seats...so I wouldn't recommend coming with a large group. They don't have wifi, but they do have water and other utensils for those who are ordering to go. Service was quite friendly and they all seemed like high school kids. I'd totally come back to Basik to order other bowls...I've got my eyes on all the other options.
author: Jodi H.

description:
My first time trying açaí in non smoothie form! LOL I know I know I'm late to the game. Where have I been all this time?!? Anyway, my friend recommended we come here and try their bowls after eyeing multiple pics on Yelp. Prices for bowls are $11 for small and $14 for large. We all ended up getting large since we didn't eat lunch yet and omg! It was such a big portion, I couldn't finish it in one sitting. Thankfully they have lids and you can grab it to go! :) this was the perfect thing to eat in 78 degree SF weather --refreshing and calming! 

I tried the Islander açaí bowl and it had coconut shavings and goji berries drizzled with honey. I'm used to eating goji berries in Chinese herbal soup so I was surprised it was in here but it meshed pretty well with everything! The granola was portioned halfway in the açaí and then on top were the fruits and other fresh ingredients! The textures were good and everything tasted delicious! I recommend trying this place if you haven't!
author: Debby N.

description: Tried several acai joints around the country, this one is by far the best. Weekends have long lines so expect to wait but it is worth it!
author: Liza H.

description:
I've come twice on a Sunday morning both times about half an hour after it opened. There was a short line already, but I think it's worth the wait. I haven't found many acai bowl places/or ones that I like, but this is one that I like. Just know that it takes about 7-10 minutes for you to get your bowl after you order if here were people in front of you. Also each specialty bowl is $11 for small and $14 for a large in case you were price conscious.

The first time I tried this place I tried their special jungle love bowl, which was a pitaya bowl with mango juice in the blend, topped with granola, kiwi, strawberries, blueberries, cacao nibs, bee pollens, and honey. I got the large because going or go home right? Well, This bowl was delicious and went above my expectations (which wasn't super high in the first place without much to compare it to). It was good for two meals!

When I went back this past Sunday, I was sad to see the sign for the jungle love bowl gone, but hey, I should try another bowl this time, which I did. I tried the Forager and this time, I went with the small size and it was enough for a meal. It was similar to the jungle love in terms of the toppings and was just as good. 

Seating is a bit sparse even early in the morning, so it's better to take your bowl to go

Def coming back whenever I'm in the area for another bowl!
author: Karen Y.

description:
I fangirl over everything acai. I eat it for breakfast. Slurp it for thirst. And slather it on my face for exfoliation. 

I've tried their acai smoothie as well as the crunch. The crunch is basically a liquified version of their bowls, you know...for the lazy folks. Think of it as astronautical food.

The acai tastes like a basic acai concoction. The crunch tastes like liquified granola with a hint of acai. It's delicious and good for on the go folks like myself who sometimes want to enjoy a light snack without chewing. #lazy
author: Connie M.

description: Best açaí in SF. Some açaí is filled with copious amounts of sugar including processed apple juice. While you can't avoid sugar, Basik is not overly sweet and hits the spot! Nice work, Basik!
author: Gianna D.

description:
This place used to be good in the beginning now they are just getting super cheap with everything. 
Yes it's cheaper to make it at home. I just wish that if i get toppings that i can actually get a good amount not a pinch. $14 for a small and it's basically just açaí powder mix. I'll just be making it at home from now on.
author: Jasmine M.

description:
I'm sure glad I literally stumbled across this place while walking the neighborhood!  It ranks up there with some of the best açaí bowls I've had, including my fav place in Lahaina, HI.  As what other reviewers said, they make some some great combinations.  Everything tastes fresh and with just the right balance between the crunch of their grains and the sweetness of the fruits.  A little pricey but the fabulous tastes makes up for it.  I was fortunate that I didn't have to experience the long lines that many reported.  It was probably because it was near closing time on a Sunday so maybe that's a tip for others!

Will be back when I'm in town!
author: Ray P.

description:
Stopped in for a quick breakfast on our last day in SF. Just wanted something light and healthy. Acai bowls and smoothies sounded perfect.

It's a small space that fills up quickly. Most people take their orders to go or eat quickly. The wait for a table doesn't take too long. We grabbed a Banyan acai bowl and Waialeah smoothie. The large acai bowl is pretty big.. you might want to split it between two people. I didn't really think about the size until it came out. The fruit they used was very fresh the bananas were sweet and soft. Great crunch texture from the granola and almonds. Nice sweetness from the honey drizzled on top. The acai was blended to perfection it wasn't runny or a frozen chunk. I liked that they layered the bowl so you're not having to dig to the bottom to get all the goods. The smoothie was great. Loved the mix of berries, acai and bananas. Just what I need to get our day started. 

Great spot overall really enjoyed their food. Will keep them in mind for our next trip.
author: Karen H.

description:
I always come here if I'm getting my hair done down the street at Eclipse. Like the name of this place would suggest, there are lots of basik people here, especially on weekends. It's a small place with not much seating so be prepared to keep an eye out for people leaving their seats or go somewhere else to enjoy your acai.

I've been getting the large crunch smoothie, because the small one is just so small. I love how the smoothies aren't room temperature or too liquidey. It's nice and cold with the perfect amount of viscosity to it. 

I've also tried the acai bowl and they are HUGE. I don't know if I would be able to finish that before everything melts (I don't like melted acai bowls). Only reason why I didn't give 5 stars is because its expensive. Like its so good, but $9 smoothies or $12 bowls is not for everyone.
author: Stephanie K.

description: Pretty Basik açaí bowls. A bit on the pricey side. A limited menu but a decent variety. It was a good bowl but it seems as if some of the strawberries were not in season so it was a little bitter. But I can't blame them! Better then using a bunch of artificial sweeteners! If I am ever in the area and feel like a healthy meal replacement I would try it again.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
I'm not in the area often, but this was just what I needed today! I've had a sore throat to the point where it hurts to eat. But I gobbled up the small Puna açaí bowl without a problem and wished I had more. The consistency was great; not icy like some other places. The bowl comes with lots of great toppings--strawberries, bananas, blueberries, granola, hemp seed, and honey! I personally would hold off on the honey because I think it's sweet enough as is. Also, the workers here are friendly, and they play great music here. 

My only reason for docking a star is that the amount of açaí you get for the price you pay is kind of little. In short, the bowl is a bit pricey. It's not something I will get often, but if I'm in the area, I will definitely treat myself to one every once in a while :) I looked over my shoulder and saw the size of the smoothies thinking maybe they're a better deal. Would definitely try those too.
author: Angie Y.

description:
I'm a fan of acai and the whole health-conscious vibe, but $11 for this regular sized cup?? I understand that we live in SF, and they charge $5 for a cup of tea or coffee, but $11 for this acai cup is a little outlandish. 

Aside from that I have no problems with the food and taste. It was really good and they use some unique ingredients like bee pollen and hemp seeds. They had a crate of bananas in the back, so you can tell that the fruits are fresh and they're not just freezing them.
author: Vasiliy M.

description: Cute little find thanks to Yelp. I was in the SF area and wanted something "healthy." I ordered their Banyan açaí bowl.: açaí, peanut butter, bee pollen, crushed almonds, hemp hearts and honey. It's a bit pricey but definitely worth it. Inside, it's very "green" scenery. There is seating indoors. Service is fast and professional.
author: Marie AK C.

description:
One of my favorite acai bowl places in SF.

It is a little pricey, but it definitely is as filling as an actual meal. 

My friends and I came on a weekday a little past lunch time and it wasn't too crowded, but people were studying. This seems like a good place to study.

I would definitely go out of my way to come here for another acai bowl. Hopefully I come back soon.
author: Allyson L.

description:
Super yummy acai bowl place!
Parking is on the street and metered so be aware! 
Inside is very hipster and a few tables for seating.

Price may be a bit high but if you get the large size, it's huge! I like to order the Forager with cacao bits, which is like little pieces of chocolate.

Also they have a point system if you sign up for it!
author: Kristie L.

description: This is the only place I know of in SF with açaí bowls that aren't soupy. Most places give a smoothie in a cup, but Basik has that more solid consistency. The options are all great, but I picked the Puna because of the gogi berries! I love that you can substitute some of the toppings! Get the large because it's a lot but way more worth it. All the staff are very friendly as well.
author: Caitlyn S.

description:
Walking in, ordering, and enjoying their delicious smoothies really is like screaming I'm a basic white bitch... but given that I'm not ashamed of my love for anything in a straw, I'm down. 

Favorite bowls - (never fully finished a bowl as they're too big)
     Kilauea - all the fruit makes it sweet without being too much
     Brazilian - classic but sooooo goodd. I always add coconut

Favorite smoothies - (the regular size is plenty to fill me up)
     Drifter - the cacao nibs with the strawberries almost makes it taste like dessert 
    Crunch - super filling with the cashew milk and the granola gives it texture that's interesting and delicious

The line can get ridiculously long on the weekend so either be prepared to wait past your hangry phase or just go on a weekday.
author: Capers B.

description:
LA popped my acai bowl superberry. Ever since then, I knew acai would be an important part of my life. When I moved up to SF a couple years ago, I searched and searched for equivalent acai. I even settled for Jamba's when they started making them (sadface - not the same). When Basik opened up, I was beyond ecstatic at the variety of options, and even more elated when my tastebuds found home: here. 

This is QUALITY. 1) They do not water it down with ice/water - you can taste the difference; 2) The texture is creamy; 3) Toppings are generous and of variety - goji berries and cocoa nibs are expensive folks! The bowls are priced with good reason; 4) For $14, you get the large and it's substantial enough I share with two people. 

Call it what you want - addict, snob, connoisseur - but I legit have woken up craving Basik's acai. No where else. And I have tried a lot of places. If you have doubts, I'll take you here myself .... just another excuse to go again zzzz #worth
author: Vickie Z.

description: Lines are a bit long but admittedly pretty good quality. takes a while to make as well
author: Annie C.

description:
The more açaí bowls I try, the more I realize how good Basik's are. Not only is the quality high and presentation on point, but the large bowl actually feels like a decent value in this city. Skip the Brazilian - it's the only bowl with an apple juice base and has the simplest toppings. 

Can't go wrong with anything else. I particularly love the Forager (cacao nibs!) and Banyan (peanut butter & banana for days).
author: Sam H.

description: Super yummy açaí bowls for not a bad price! The place was also really nicely decorated.
author: Xoxojarely V.

description:
Favorite açaí spot in town!

A large Brazilian with strawberries is my go to order for sharing. If you don't have a huge appetite, the small is plenty for one person. 

Occasionally the blends gets a bit tart when you get to the bottom but nothing that a little extra honey can't fix. Basik has a great variety for seasonal fruits and flavors as well.
author: Jenn Y.

description:
Idk why we waited in line for 20 minutes for this. Maybe because everyone talks about it and we thought it'd be that good? The açaí is pretty good, but not the best / not worth the wait for me personally - there are definitely other places in the city that will remain my go-to for good, yummy açaí that I don't have to wait in line for (ask me if you want recommendations)

The only stand-out thing about this place is the size of the large. 3 of us girls split 2 larges cause we were hungryyyy and it was actually too much for us (and trust me, we are not the type to not finish food, especially açaí bowls!!)
author: Nicole L.

description: These gourmet acai bowls are amazing! I love the banyan and the islander. I always bring friends here and everything they have tried they have also loved. Sometimes the lines are long but it is worth the wait. There is not much room to eat, but table turnover rate is fast, so I always find somewhere to sit and eat.
author: Nepheli A.

description: My first time going and although the flavor is there - the portions are miniature considering the amount of money it is. A small acai bowl (with a $1 tip) was $12. Even though they look like a decent size when presented to you - it's all fruit toppings and granola. It was barely 1/4 acai. If I wanted a fruit bowl I would have been able to make that at home for far cheaper!
author: Christine J.

description:
Mmmm, not usually a fan of anything basic but Basik is an exception :) Acai bowls are perfect for a nice and hot day. Super refreshing and portable for picnics. 

I haven't had many Acai bowls aside from making my own and one in Hawaii but Basik did not disappoint :) They give you a big portion for the large though this place is a bit pricy. Fruits were super fresh, acai was extra refreshing and the hints of honeycomb were so yummy! One thing I would note is that I wish they put more bananas. I would suggest either walking here if you live in the area but otherwise, parking in this area is pretty tough. I'll be back to try their smoothies and other bowls!
author: Shelly W.

description: Love the vibes of this place! It was really cute and they had a lot of seats inside too, despite the small space. I ordered the Islander! The gojiberries they added inside was sooooooo delicious. It added that extra crunch and sweetness. Definitely would come back for another bowl/cup. The only thing is that the fruits they used weren't sweet at all. The bananas and strawberries were so hard to bite into...for $15 I feel like they could've provided better quality of fruits.
author: Fei S.

description:
Basik had been on my "to try" list forever - worth the wait! :)

I'm somewhat picky since I don't like acai that's too sweet or icy, and Basik did not disappoint. It is somewhat expensive, but acai typically is and the large bowls here are HUGE. I can eat a lot of acai - but the large is DEFINITELY for sharing.

Nice trendy decor as well, though would be nice to have just a bit more seating!
author: Connie Q.

description:
Basik serves my favorite acai bowl in the city: the islander. The goji berries just make the bowl magical.

I docked one star because the lines are long and they move slowly. I ended up in line for 45 minutes last weekend. Ugh. However, on sunny days when I'm working from home, getting an acai bowl from Basik is pure bliss.

Super fresh ingredients, puffy granola, fresh berries, chewy goji berries, all drizzled with honey.
author: Grace C.

description: I am a huge fan of Basik Cafe! Usually, there is a long line, but my friend and I were able to get in pretty quickly. Lots of unique toppings: spirulina, bee pollen, hemp, etc. Their açaí bowls are the best! A little pricey- but worth it! I ordered the banyan bowl and added blueberries! This is my second time here and I will definitely be going back.
author: Zinia G.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place after going to the gym nearby, but the line is always out the door. I took advantage of the week of Christmas when most people were out of town to come here. No wait for me and one delicious açaí bowl!

Price is steep but the banyan açaí bowl is the most amazing açaí bowl I've tried in SF.

Blend: açaí, natural peanut butter and house made cashew
Toppings: granola, crushed almonds, hemp seeds, bee pollen and honey
author: Christine C.

description:
*** In Short ***

Tasty acai bowls for right proper millennials.

*** In Depth ***

Leave it to a good friend's younger sister to introduce me to acai bowls, which, until now, I had assumed were more akin to a yogurt parfait than the fruit smoothies they really are. Having no other baseline to compare against, I can only speak for these on their own: fresh, tasty, not overly sweet, great on a hot day, and given how filling one can be, a good value for the price.

Five flavors to choose from, from a small single serving to a larger double for just a wee bit more, and served up pretty quick. Other reviews mention hefty lines, but when we went at 4pm on a Saturday, we were the only ones waiting, with just two others in the cafe.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - The cafe itself is on a bit of an incline, while the interior is a bit on the smaller side. The cashier is completely accessible, but aside from a lower, accessible counter right by the door, all other seating is comprised of high tops.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description:
Favorite acai bowl place ever! This is your place to go for acai bowls if you like them, love them, or have never had one.

The first time I went there I ordered the Banyan bowl, and have never been able to go back! The blend consists of acai, peanut butter and cashew milk and the toppings include granola, almonds, hemp seeds, bee pollen, and honey. Peanut butter in an acai bowl might sound a bit weird to some, but trust me, it's a game changer in all the right ways :) They also make their granola in house, which adds to the deliciousness of this bowl. 

The only reason I am docking a star is because of the price- $14 for a large acai bowl definitely makes Basik Cafe a place to go to when you want to treat yourself.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
Addicted to açaí bowls!

The first time I went to Basik Cafe, I got super lucky and managed to find an unusually short line. I've started to go to Crunch on Polk, and Basik is a great pre/post workout meal. It's only a 6-10 minutes walk. Unfortunately, weekend mornings are packed, so try to get there early. 

My favorite açaí bowl and probably the best bang for my buck is a regular-sized Brasilian ($8); large is $12. It's the most basic bowl. The regular size is enough for a full-sized meal, about 16 oz. The other açaí bowls are $11 for a regular and $14 for a large. Smoothies are also a reasonable price for the quality and amount. 

There is limited seating, but enough for a small cafe crowd. The typical crowd is young families and friends.
author: Joanna S.

description:
Best Acai bowls in San Francisco. Their Hawaii roots shine through at this place. Small, quaint and quick. 

The Banyan is my favorite - I always add blackberries. Their ingredients are very fresh. 

The small is plenty - size large is a massive task. Their granola is crisp and always tasty. 

Here every few weeks.
author: John A.

description:
So I tell myself I'm going to save money because eating out is expensive. Despite the acai bowls being $11-14, I somehow rationalize to myself that it's fine.

Because you know what? the acai bowls here are DAMN FINE. They're delicious and made by hand - customizing it to your satisfaction. I always opt for the large because the portion to price difference ratio is flashing, HELLO. OBVIOUSLY GET THE LARGE. You get more out of your bucks.

I should really just buy all the ingredients myself and make it at home so I don't have to spend $11-14 a week but...convenience and time.
author: Cheri C.

description: Their açaí bowls are pretty darn good, but of course way over priced. They are super quick and usually have a line out the door. Ingredients are all really fresh and delicious!
author: Aya O.

description:
Question: is it pronounced as "Basic" café? If yes, it's genius. I was curious to come here because of the play on the name + seeing a line of both men and women in Lululemon. Seriously, my type of crowd. 

There is a myriad of acai bowls you can choose from and they're delicious. Especially refreshing on a sunny day. Fruits are fresh, staff are young & friendly, and shop is decently sized. 

Smoothies are tasty too, but without a doubt order an acai bowl or two or three.
author: Jenn H.

description:
I've always enjoyed Basik Cafe and recommended it to my coworkers. Recently, I've had a string of bad service from messing up an order and confusion with orders which at one instance, I ended up waiting more than an hour just to get my order. Even then I thought those are minimal to give them anything less than four stars. 

I went there today to get my usual group order, this time I ordered 8 bowls. I was surprised when I saw my bill at $140.96 when I was expecting a little less at $108. I was told by the cashier that they started charging service fees for orders 5 or more, that it's a "new thing" they started doing. I asked how much was the service fee cashier can't give me the percentage, instead told me that I have to just do the Math. 

I thought the food has priced itself out of my budget. The service fee by the way is 20% of total bill plus tax which in my case svc fee $21.60 + 11.36 tax. which added a total of $32.96 on my bill just because I ordered more than 5 items. 

On the way out I asked for a bag but I was told that they started charging for those too and to top it off, When I got to work I found out that they messed up the one I ordered even though I gave them a word pro copy of the order. 

It was disappointing...
author: Ryan A.

description:
I never leave reviews, but I was compelled to write this. The use of whole/half/quarter almonds with the Acai Bowls is the worst example of judgement I've encountered in a LONG time. It completely ruined the texture, consistency, flavor, and experience that a great Acai bowl can be.

If you don't get almonds, it'll be fantastic. Great ingredients, etc etc. But their use of almonds shows to me no thought from the company in regards to how the bowl is supposed to "flow". If they had thinly sliced and roasted the almonds I think that would have worked quite well. But you're enjoying this nice smooth Acai bowl with delicious fruit when all of a sudden you hit a massive, effectively frozen whole almond, or actually multiple! I picked them all out and they must have put in half a cup or more of almonds. I implore you to pass on the almonds if you don't want the granola. For $15 with tax what a mistake.
author: Stefan B.

description: Their available bowls come in large portions and can definitely fill you up. You can also customize their preset bowls if you do not like some or their ingredients. The prices are a bit high. I learned that they are actually a chain now. The vibe is definitely cute, but I would only go if I am in the area craving for acai.
author: Charlene F.

description:
Pretty bomb acai bowls. The difference in price between a large and a regular is only a few bucks but the large is about twice the size. Recommend bringing a friend and splitting a large for this acai trip to make economical sense.

I crave acai after a long night / weekend of alcohol consumption because it makes me feel like I'm doing something good for my body.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Space is open and clean but limited (got pretty lucky someone left just as we finished ordering). On a side note, I was pretty amused at the proportion of people in workout gear; made me feel as if i worked out too and came in for a healthy snack

I was pretty excited to randomly walk past this place and find out they served acai bowls! Overall I really enjoyed the Islander acai bowl, you can't argue against all the superfood + other healthy ingredients in an acai bowl. I didn't like how chewy the dried goji berries on top were though, (internal monologue) but it's a superfood so shut up, eat it and enjoy the positive health benefits

$14/large bowl is pretty steep imo (the small which is like one third or half the size of the large is $11) but worth the quality of ingredients!
author: Mimi T.

description: The reason I'm giving two stars is because I wanted inline for 20 minutes, after waiting inline I was greeted by a welcoming cashier. He explained the menu great so I ordered a Puna bowl. The thing is after I ordered the Puna bowl a man with a dog walked in the kitchen and all the kitchen workers began petting the dog. I did not see them wash there hands neither. I love dogs but not in a kitchen we're you are serving the public that is a no no !!!!! However after that I got my bowl and put it in the trash because I was so disgusted. The star comes from the good customer service.  I attached a photo as well.
author: Demario P.

description: The was a line when we arrived on a Saturday morning. The place was pretty small so people were in an out mostly. The line moved pretty quickly. I had the Puna acai bowl in the small size. The large was double the size but only a couple of dollars extra, so I recommend sharing it with a friend. The bowl was good but I feel like you can't really go wrong with acai bowls.
author: Maggi W.

description:
I love Basik! The line is always pretty long, but it's worth the wait. The acai bowls are such a fresh and healthy meal, and the large bowls are really filling. My favorite is the Forager. I wish there was more seating outside, because it's always hard to actually eat it there. 

It's the closest place to feeling like you are vacationing in Hawaii!
author: Lauren A.

description: This place is bomb!!!! We had to wait around 15 min in line, but it was worth it. Best acai bowl I've had in CA. I got the islander and my boyfriend got the banyan. I loved the goji berries and coconut shavings in the islander; would definitely order again. I'm usually not a fan of nuts in my acai bowls, but the nuts in the banyan weren't overpowering; would also order this one again. Shoutout to lululemon SF for recommending this place to us!!
author: Kelly C.

description:
Favorite açaí in the city! You may have to wait in a long line, but it's always worth it to me. 

My go to is the Islander, I sub the hemp milk for apple juice and get the coconut shavings on the side (sometimes it can be too much coco for me).
author: Bianca B.

description:
Really good Acai bowels and the pros outweigh the cons for sure! 
Pros - made to order, fresh ingredients and super tasty!! 
Cons - long wait time on weekends, kind of on the expensive side. 
Worth it? YES!
author: Jack B.

description: This is one of my new favorite spots for acai in the Bay Area! It's in a quiet part of the city, and parking was easy to find. The inside of the cafe was really modern and clean. I got a large Brazilian, which was $12. I got it really fast, and it tasted amazing. I will definitely be back!
author: Kendall C.

description: Finally was able to try this place and I love it! I got the Islander acai bowl and its so good. You get you pick which size you want regular or large. Limited seating place and street parking only. I would definitely come back to try other bowls.
author: Jami F.

description: Small, modern place with big windows and seating. Service took about 10 mins and it's delicious and fresh! 5 stars
author: Lily T.

description:
If there was a show about my life, it'd be called "True Life: I'm Addicted to Acai Bowls". 

I'm always thinking about where and when I'm gonna get my next fix (acai fix, that is). Shawn C. doesn't support this addiction, so I knew that I had to take advantage of my time alone and make it out here to Basik Cafe. 

This place is poppin'. Came around 1pm on a Sunday and the line was out the door the whole ~hour I was there. 

I got a regular sized Puna and it was delicious. $11 is pretty steep but they do not skimp on quality toppings here. 

A large is only $3 more but it's like double the size. SO WORTH. Passed on that though because I was by myself and I'd be all acai'd out.
author: Laverne N.

description:
The acai bowls were really good here, very fresh and they have lids if you want to get your order to go. 

they also offer smoothies if that's more your thing, but the granola and texture amongst everything was really nice. 

Taking a star off cuz the place is so small, everyone just hovers until a spot opens then everyone kind of dives for it... that's a little awkward
author: Mandi W.

description: This place is extremely over-rated. The acai bowls don't taste great and what's worse, service is really lacking. I asked a basic question about sizing to the cashier and she was completely rude. The only reason this place gets 2 stars is because the portions are huge, which must be because their product isn't that great to begin with.
author: Dani P.

description: This is my favorite place for an açaí bowl in San Francisco. Fresh, healthy ingredients with compostable bowls!!!
author: Allison M.

description: Their crunch smoothie was so good and cashier is super cute and funny! My boyfriend got the acai smoothie and he loved it!
author: Kathy D.

description:
My first acai bowl! I honestly didn't think the acai bowls on the menu were that different from each other, but I got the Puna bowl (the smaller size) and found it to be very refreshing. The portion size is about just right for a light breakfast or snack. Small bowls are $11 and large bowls are $14. A bit pricey as all acai bowls are, but so healthy!

Taste | 4
Atmosphere | 4
Presentation | 4
Service | 4
OVERALL | 4
author: Lana L.

description: Who isn't in love with Basik Cafe ? They have the best tasting açaí bowls in all of San Francisco. You can taste how fresh the ingredients are; their made-to-order individually blended bowls make them the apotheosis of açaí bowls. I highly recommend the Banyan bowl (tip: ask for no honey as it makes it a little too sweet). The Mayan smoothie is also amazing - the mint and cacao compliment the açaí perfectly. Lines can get dangerously long on weekends but it's always worth the wait. Thanks for being the best !
author: Rachel P.

description: Love love love their acai bowl and their unique toppings! This is definitely on top of the list of places to visit every time I am back in town!
author: Merve C.

description:
This is the best acai bowl I've had thus far aside from the ones I've had in Hawaii, but even then, Basik's bowls are up there. Unlike many places in the mainland, these bowls actually have acai flavor and aren't super sweet or blended with a bunch of other ambiguous filler berries to cheat you out of having actual acai.

I believe the regular size is $10 and the large size is $14, but the large is probably twice the size of the regular. Usually I order the large but share with a friend, which is perfect (sometimes we even struggle to finish our halves) and more economical. I love that they layer the granola instead of just piling it all on top which makes it a nice even distribution. 

I usually opt for the drifter which is cashew milk, cacao, and acai blended for the base, then topped with granola, banana, cacao nibs, crushed almonds, strawberries, and honey. If you're more of a blueberry person, they will sub the strawberries out at no charge, which is what I do.

My mouth is watering just writing this review and thinking about the acai bowls at Basik. Mm!
author: Stacey L.

description:
Shop is cute and portions are generous, but the quality of the base is just not on par with that of Blue Hawaiian or Project Juice.

I had the Banyan and it tasted sour and not creamy enough. The line also took a long time to process, likely because each order is made to order (vs batched). I waited about 15 minutes with 4-5 people in front of me, which was long.

Positives are that the store is chic and the interior is spacious. The staff are nice and the portions/toppings are generous - they do not skimp.
author: Amy G.

description:
My favorite ACAI BOWL in the city! The line is way crazier now then when they first open. But the chances of them selling out is less now. They are more prepared for the overwhelming need of their amazing bowls and smoothies. No best time to come, the luck of the draw I would say. Overall the wait time isn't bad, the line moves. 

Been a customer since day one and super excited to have Basik Cafe in this neighborhood. I love this place. My favorite is their **FORAGER Asai Bowl. its made and blend with acai, cacao powder, and cashew mylk "milk". Topped with granolas, bananas, strawberries, raw cashews, cacao nibs and honey. It taste so good and refreshing. The toppings is a super nice added touch, especially if you add some coco flakes. YUM! I think their regular size is good for me but only $3 more dollars for the large.

Also I love their **ACAI SMOOTHIE. Made with acai, strawberries. banana and mango juice. I always add in some coconut flakes for a little more texture. Large is the way to go because its so good, you will finish the small quickly.
author: Sandy B.

description: Love this place. The ingredients are always fresh and delicious! I love the Puna Bowl with almonds added to it. There's almost always a line so plan accordingly. Great spot to go to start your morning or to refuel after a workout. Will keep coming back fo sho!
author: Alex S.

description: I get an acai bowl here probably almost every Saturday. The line is long but it moves fast and the acai bowls are welllll worth the wait. Aside from being the best hangover cure in San Francisco, the bowls are BOMB. They're made -to-order with fresh ingredients and the staff is super friendly and accommodating to special requests. Not enough good things to say about this spot!
author: Marisa R.

description:
Basik has delicious acai bowls and smoothies.

You might think: hmmm, fruit, granola, acai blended into non-cow milk pudding-like custard...what's the big deal?

Well, the combinations are really tasty.
The ingredients are combined and served fresh-to-order,
There are many choices for every taste...cacao bits (check), raw cashews (check), coconut (check), strawberries (check), banana slices (check), etc etc...

These bowls are not inexpensive. 

But how important is the food you eat the first thing in the morning? 
Muffins or other pastries are a lovely splurge and, maybe, you'll think this acai stuff is also a splurge. True. 

Give acai a try and you'll see why there are long lines here.
author: Joanna T.

description: Excellent bowls in the city and second to only Judahlicious which is pretty far for me.. negated a star cause the line is always insane so that's the only deterrent !
author: Jade B.

description:
No clue what Acai is or how to pronounce it but- YUM. I have been hearing about these bowls from people that are much cooler than me for quite some time. 

I came here post TRX workout, feeling a little shaky. I ordered the Puna, size small. Why the hell did I order the small?! So delicious. I almost went back and got another one. 

But...$11 is too much for something that doesn't have protein and can't pass as a real meal. Kale salad with chicken, $11. Bowl with smoothie, 1/4 banana and 4 cup up strawberries, not worth $11. 

I also wasn't a fan of the cold interior that felt unfinished. If I'm paying $11 for a non meal give me somewhere fancy and relaxing to sit.
author: Alison C.

description:
Am I the only one who thinks that the name of this place is hilarious? After all, there are few things more basic than an acai bowl.

Their name aside, their acai bowls are no joke. My favorites are the Islander and the Puna, but you can't go wrong with any of the acai bowls on their menu. They're all super fresh and taste great, and the acai itself is the perfect texture (I hate it when it's too runny or icy). Service is friendly too.

Minus 1 star because the price is pretty steep for the amount that you get, especially for the small ($11), which isn't really big enough for a meal. If you want the best value, go for the large ($14). That is, if you can finish it, because that thing is humongous.
author: Sara L.

description:
I love basik cafe! And my basic self always orders the Brasilia acai bowl. I always ask for no bananas topping and replace them with berries and they're always super nice with letting me do that. 

However, I went last Tuesday and idk the workers were not getting people's orders right. The girl before me asked for berries (which she paid extra for) and they forgot to give them to her. Then I realized they never topped mine with honey and then the guy after me had a smoothie and they forgot something in his as well...
author: Yvonne L.

description: This was my first time here and definitely not my last. Super cute interior in a nice area. I got the Drifter in a size small and it was not only delicious!! but also the perfect size. I'll be coming back to try the acai bowls!
author: Tanya O.

description:
Holy acai bowls! The large here is ginormous and is more than enough for 2 people (probably could've fed 4 honestly.)

We came by on a Sunday afternoon and it was not too packed. There was a line, but there were still seats available inside and out. I believe we ordered the Puna bowl and added bee pollen to it. Comes with a TON of fruits and granola so you're not just left with melted acai at the end. The consistency is a bit more watery/smoothie than I prefer, so that was a minus for me. All in all, a good acai bowl!

Bebebar in the Mission is still my favorite acai bowl place in the city. They really get it right there, and I think it's the closest to what we had in Hawaii. Blue Hawaii on the Embarcadero takes second place and Basik Cafe takes third. Blue Hawaii is the boyfriend's #1 fav though.
author: Doris K.

description:
"WAKE UP & LIVE!"

For those that know me, I'm a sucker for nice decor and acai bowl. I've tried plenty of acai joint's all over the Bay Area and Basik Cafe is probably one of the best one I've had. It does tend to get crowded but the line moves fast. I went with the Puna which includes: acai, hemp milk, keahole grown spirulina, granola, strawberries, local banana, organic hemp seed, fresh blueberries & a drizzle of local honey. 

Prices:
- Small $11
- Large $14
A little pricey but definitely worth your bucks.

Conclusion: I would highly recommend to try this spot if you're around the area or if you're craving for some good Acai.
author: Danny L.

description:
So Bebebar in the Mission will always fill my acai shaped hole, Basik is a close second. 

As far as toppings, they offer a plethora of fancy/healthy additions that are far from basic ;]

Goji berries, granola, bananas, mulberries, strawberries, blueberries, seasonal berries, coconut shavings, bee pollen, hemp hearts, several types of nuts, cacao nibs, chia seeds, pumpkin seeds, and nut butters. I like the Puna and the Islander bowls. If you're trying to cut the calories, omit the granola and get quinao puffs instead. Never had a smoothie here but they all sound delish.

The price point is a bit high, $11 for a small. Also, while they advertise specialty Kona coffee, IMO it's kind of meh/blah. But this isn't a coffee shop so I let that slide. My only other complaint is they don't have a posted phone number. The website has none for the SF location and this one on Yelp just rings and rings and rings. So just know ya can't order ahead and pick it up and on Saturday/Sunday mornings the line can go down the street.
author: Miriam M.

description:
Amazing acai bowl and smoothie shop! 
Pros: delicious, beautiful presentation, great atmosphere
Cons: Pricy, prone to long lines 

I stumbled across Basik the other day and there was a line out the door.  When I surveyed the menu I thought to myself "This is obviously just another over priced, pseudo-healthy yogurt store". However, a couple hours later when I was dehydrated and desperately needing a bathroom, I decided to cave and go to Basik to get a smoothie. Accompanied by a good friend who indulged in one of their beautiful acai bowls, I was incredibly impressed with their products. Not only are the gorgeous to look at and use extremely clean, healthy ingredients, but they actually taste amazing! While $11 is a bit pricy for a smoothie, it was worth it!
author: Quinn Li O.

description:
Hit this spot up on a hot day, but luckily we got there right before the line got long. 

The large bowl is pretty large and filled me up about 3/4 of the way through. I don't get full easily. I like that they have pre-designed bowls or build your own. The girlfriend and I ordered the Banyan and Forager with extra peanut butter. Both bowls weren't super sweet, tasted fresh, and the fruit/condiments were fresh. I was happy with the amount of granola they threw in without having to pay for extra.

I enjoyed this Acai bowl a lot, but wouldn't say it's my favorite in the City.
author: John M.

description:
I could eat their acai bowls every morning! It's a healthy yet tasty option just a little pricey.

I got the large Brasilian ($12) which was acai and apple juice topped with granola, banana, and honey. It was so good and not overly sweet! There was a big difference in size between the small and large. I'd recommend if you're hungry to get the large since it's only $4 more.

Service was nice and there was some seating inside. They also serve kona coffee ($3) and smoothies.
author: Linda X.

description: Yum yum yum - love their acai bowls! Go for the large, only $2 more than the regular and you get basically 2x the amount! I can finish a large acai bowl myself, absolutely delicious! My favorite acai bowl place in the city!
author: Cynthia H.

description:
Best acai bowl in the city! I am allergic to some of the ingredients in the granola and asked the cashier if I could swap out the granola for other ingredients, she kindly agreed and changed my order. 
When the acai bowl arrived, it was PILED with extra fruits and toppings (in compensation of no granola?). The fruits tasted great and the acai on the bottom was not too sweet, not too slushy or too watery. 
I also would like to note that the lighting is perfect inside the cafe, the interior is super nice and comfortable with just enough sun coming in! perfect for photos too.  

The only downside is the long lines that seem to be a permanent situation no matter what time of the day you go..but this is also a problem for everything good in San Francisco..
author: Shelly L.

description:
So, Heather H really wanted to not like this spot just because of the sheer lines. One day she found herself parched and in the mood for something sweet and waited the 10 precious minutes of her life for a Basik Bowl. (Not knowing much about the content) she got a Banyan--from then on she was hooked! Do they put crack in the acai she asked herself? 
Looking at the size of the large bowl, she never had the slightest idea she could finish it all... and there she was, licking the remains. 
Nothing Basic about Basik! Except some of the clientele on occasion :-)
author: Jill F.

description: I cannot express how much I LOVVVEEE this place! Cute little cafe on Polk St. Nob Hill area that serves the best acai bowls ever! This place is nice and clean inside, aesthetically pleasing, friendly staff, and consistently great food. I've never been disappointed coming here. I love how healthy all the menu options are and they serve coffee as well. A nice, healthy alternative breakfast when you don't want to pig out! Definitely worth checking out
author: Vanessa C.

description: I ordered Basik Cafe's Acai Bowl through Doordash. The acai base was really refreshing, light and not sugary at all. The berries on top were really fresh. Definitely will order again. It's a great hot summer snack! :D
author: Clare L.

description:
Overpriced (delicious) açai bowls, and for $1 more, you can get up to 5 blackberries! These are really good, but I don't think I'll be back based on what you actually get for the price. 

Bonzai bowls in San Clemente / Huntington Beach is still our go-to.
author: Morgan G.

description: I loved their Kona location so I was pumped to try their SF location out when I was in the city for a vacation. Same great taste, I'm a big fan of the Islander bowl but they're all good. The line for this place at 10:30AM on Sunday was HUGE but it actually moved along at a pretty good clip so stick it out, it's worth the wait.
author: Michael D.

description: Finally got to try this acai bowl place twice since it was really hyped up!  I see what the hype is about and I must say this is a go to acai bowl place now.  The first time I went there was a line so I did wait awhile but it's worth it!  I always order the islander.  I think the gojiberries go with everything else.  I love blackberries as well so adding that on was wonderful.  It is a bit pricey but I definitely think it's worth the splurge.  Highly recommend coming to this place if you want a healthy and refreshing snack!
author: Mikayla M.

description:
My third visit to Basik, tried one of their seasonal warm bowls. The Holiday Crisp has warm quinoa topped with strawberry and cranberry compote, fresh strawberries, granola and honey. Good but if you haven't been here before, you shouod try the acai bowl first (BANYAN). The quinoa bowl is slightly smaller but hits a different spot -- more of a small healthy lunch vs a treat. 

Definitely recommend if you're in the neighborhood Quality ingredients, sizable portions, and delicious!
author: Dennis H.

description:
AVOID! I was super excited to get an acai bowl here after seeing the huge line on the street. I went in to check out the menu and take a quick peek at how they make the bowls. When I looked through the glass, the staff rudely pointed at a sign that said "Don't be that guy" and motioned for me to turn around and go away. I was really confused... they don't want people to look at them making the food? Then they started rudely laughing at me, pointing to the sign again, and motioning for me to go.

I really wanted to like this place, but not doing business with a bunch of jerks. Went and got my girlfriend who was waiting in line and we went elsewhere.

 I'll be telling my friends to AVOID THIS PLACE.
author: Feross A.

description:
If you want Acai, then yes it's 5 stars.  If you want something else, then, well don't come here! 

It's not cheap, but where have you ever gotten acai for cheap, other than maybe in Brazil.  It's not as good as the acai I got in Brazil, but really, nothing is.  It's not even as good as the acai in Hawaii but you know what, it's here and you try taking an acai cup from either of those two places and keep it from melting, so yeah, I give Basik 5 stars.

I'm a fan of two things really: the Brasilian acai cup and the Acai smoothie.  I don't like bananas so I get it with no bananas but get strawberries instead.  I kind of think the smoothie is more enjoyable and tastier, and a little cheaper, but if you want to replace a meal, you probably want something you can eat with a spoon.

If they have fresh fruit, check out what they have because sometimes you can add on fresh peaches or pineapples and it's super yummy!

The line is often times really long and goes outside the door.  If it looks long then yes it will take a while, and a lot of times I won't wait because it will take you 15-20 minutes just to get to order and then another 15-20 minutes to get your food because they'll get that backed up.  If the line is still inside the store, be patient and it should be fine.

Bathroom is a single and it's locked with a code you have to get from them.

They used to close the store exactly at closing time, regardless of if you were standing in line. Not sure if they loosened up on that policy but if it's getting close to closing time, you might want to check because they have been known to close the window on people still standing in line at closing time.
author: Traci H.

description:
Highly disappointed esp after reading all the positive reviews on Yelp.

I got the Forager açaí bowl and although it was refreshing, it lacked a lot of flavors. The açaí part of the bowl was highly disappointed because the blends ratio was way off. Lacked flavor and tasted like it was blended with not enough ingredients. That being said, there was more topping than the actual açaí in the bowl. I paid for $11 worth of strawberries. :/ 


Not likely to bring anyone or come back again. Project Juice will still forever be my favorite.
author: Jenny S.

description: Best Acai bowl in the city. I loved the selection and found myself to be quite full after. Odds are you'll be waiting in a line outside so bring those SF layers. There isn't a lot of seating, but there's always a dope playlist.
author: Laurisha C.

description:
Pris: Consistently flavorful and delicious smoothies and bowls. A great array of health minded toppings. Always walk away feeling satisfied with the treat.

Cons: the small space seldom has tables available or enough room for more than two people.
author: Diana B.

description:
I've been a huge acai fan for a while and finally got a chance to try this place! Went on a hot Sunday afternoon so the line was a little long but I didn't mind since I had my good friend with me to keep me company.  Overall the experience was great.  The shop is nice and small and the seating is timed perfectly (they also have outdoor seating).  Since they only serve acai bowls and drinks/smoothies, there's no need to really sit in for a long time, so it's likely you'll have a seat to enjoy your bowl!

All the bowls seemed similar but had little tweaks to it so it was hard for me to decide on what I wanted!  Eventually ordered the Forager since I was feeling chocolatey. Overall, it was a really good proportioned and picturesque acai bowl. Every bite had fruit and granola in it and I was satisfied after a small bowl.
author: Tiffany Z.

description:
This place is hands down one of my favorite places I have ever been to. While visiting San Fran last week, I had breakfast at this location each day (It's THAT good). If you ever get the chance to visit, try the Islander! It's literally heaven in my mouth. I also added blackberries. I wish they had more locations! 

The vibe, customer service and product are top notch and it's evident that this business is doing something very right. 

PSA: There is VERY limited seating. I was able to get a seat each time I went, mostly because I was ready to throw elbows when I seen someone about to get up.
author: .. Cay ..

description: Seriously so good and aesthetically pleasing!! Great customer service and in a convenient location, not too busy. The BANYAN was really really good. Living in San Diego we're bowls are made by Brazilians, this place was just as good. I'll be back. Yumm
author: Victoria D.

description: Delicious açaí bowls :) The presentation is nice and the small size is big enough to fill you up. Came out quick after the order and they have a lid in case you want it to-go. Not much else to say other than highly recommend!
author: Hannah K.

description:
When you are travelling, getting a healthy breakfast is hard. Real damn hard. Especially in The States where there is like eggs, bacon and potatoes everywhere. Seriously, I needed some fruit. Thank you Yelp once again for saving the day. 

Basik Cafe is a cute pop up feel cafe. Decked inside with a shipping container and a few tables inside. You will need to wait in a line though. It's a popular store. But, worth the wait, the acaci bowls are delish! 

There are two sizes. But seriously, the small size is more than enough! I tried the Islander. It was really fresh and tasty. Banana and strawberry base with hemp milk, granola, berries, hemp hearts and honey. I really enjoyed it! So much so, I went back the next day to get another one. An acai bowl is full of antioxidants. So, it gives you a whole lot of energy for the start of the day! It's not cheap though, but I think it's worth paying a little extra for something so good quality. I definitely recommend you try!
author: Anita D.

description: My favourite acai bowl place! I always order Banyan or Puna with additional cashews on top. Service here is very friendly. I come here every week!
author: Rebecca M.

description: I like that place. One thing that I don't like is waiting in a long line. Except  that everything, especially acai bowls I love them ))))
author: Muhammadsodiq O.

description:
My first acai bowl experience was at Basik Cafe! It was really really good. I loved how healthy and fresh everything tasted. It seems pretty pricey for what it is, but it was a nice and filling snack in the middle of the day after a workout.

You'll likely have to wait 20 minutes in line because they make each bowl individually. There are a few seats inside but it's better for takeout.
author: Nina H.

description: Love these açaí bowls!!!! My favorite is the Banyan. Definitely get the large size, it's way more bang for your buck!
author: Emmi B.

description: Just as good as the original location in Kona. My favorite is the Banyan bowl with added strawberries because you get both the nuttiness/protein with the sweetness of the berries.  YUM.  I seriously crave these bowls all the time.
author: Annie R.

description: It seemed ridiculous how many people were lined up to eat here considering it's just açai bowls, but man it's pretty dang delicious.  I had a smoothie which was amazing.
author: Reggie G.

description: The long line was worth the wait. I can see why people come to Basik after a long workout the bowls are huge! Most of the other acai bowl places don't give enough granola for my liking. Basik had just the right amount: A LOT
author: Alex S.

description: Acai bowls are pretty big now huh? I honestly don't know the hype behind it. We have places in Seattle that has them but I never made the effort to get them so when I got to SF and my friends bf talked about this awesome acai bowls I wanted to come to this specific place to try them. The wait was pretty insane; 30/40 min but I get it. They hand make every individual order. I'm kind of glad they do that because I'm allergic to banana and even if I wanted to say fuck it and just have them throw them in there and eat if. I'd still deal with the side affect later on so with that being said. My bowl was pretty boring because I had to cut out all the bananas. Anywho, I order the forager bowl without banana. It was pretty good. I don't have any cons or any pros to it because I didn't see what was so special about this acai bowls but I suppose it's good for your body? Meh, I'm glad I tried it in SF not so sure I'd want it while I'm in Seattle. Service was great though! The girl helping us was so sweet!!
author: Linh N.

description: First time visit and we will definitely be back! My husband tried the Banyan bowl and I had the Mayan smoothie both were absolutely delicious! Can't wait to go back
author: Arcie V.

description:
I may never find an acai bowl as good as this little place off the highway in Kauai, but this place is a pretty darn close second. Yes, it's pricey, and yes, there's a long line, but if you're prepared for those two things, then this place is a nice treat every once in a while as a special treat. I think this is one of the best acai bowls in the city, and I've tried at least 3 other places.

The small is a decent size for $11 and will fill you up, and the large is massive - like the size of a large tub of yogurt. It's certainly large enough to fill up 2 people, and at $14 is not too bad for what you get.

I got the Banyan, which has the acai blend, peanut butter, almond milk, granola, bananas, honey, bee pollen, almonds, and hemp hearts. I love any acai bowl with peanut butter, granola, and bananas, and this was excellent. They didn't skimp on the toppings, and it the acai base wasn't too sweet.

I'm sure I'd be happy with any of their other acai bowls, as all the other combinations look great. I wouldn't necessarily come here all the time though. While this is certainly all the rage, and deemed really healthy with antioxidants, etc. in the acai, there's still a lot of natural sugar in here. It's better than a bunch of refined sugar, but it's still sugar all the same. I wouldn't make this a habit of coming every single week after the gym. 

I'll certainly come here again for more acai bowls, but with a friend so that I can split the large size. Beware that the lines can get long (can be 15-30 min) and if you go on the weekend you may have to listen to a lot of Marina girls rehash bad decisions they made on the weekend when they come with all their friends post-workout or as they nurse a hangover, and you have to stand in line next to them for 30 min.
author: Christina L.

description: This is my favorite place to eat on Polk St. Gotta admit, I didn't love it the first time I tried this place, but now I'm hooked. I've tried every one of their acai bowls. The forager and the brasilian are probably my favorite. I especially love it when they have a special or seasonal bowl that's something off menu.  I've only tried the crunch smoothie but it's also super good. Although the bowls are a bit pricey, they're absolutely delicious.
author: Annie H.

description:
I never knew what the big deal was about acai bowls, but after trying Basik Cafe, I can understand the addiction. Basik Cafe has turned me in to an acai fiend. 

I've tried their all their bowls and in all honesty they are all equally so good. I think when it comes down to what's the best, it's all based on your preference. But i do highly recommend their Puna and Islander. Now you may think $9 is ridiculous for a small smoothie bowl, but don't be fooled! These bowls are packed and fulfilling that you actually may be struggling to finish. But compared to lots of other acai bowl places, this place is fairly cheaper. 

This is hands down my favorite acai bowl place in the city!
author: Denzell S.

description:
Service has went a bit downhill from when it opened. 

Average wait time is ~2-4 minute per person. So if you're 10 people deep in the line, expect to wait 20-30 minutes to place an order. 

Stood in line for 20, and left.... all three times. Stopped going.
author: Jared N.

description:
I waited weeks to come try this place!
Place is cute, staff are friendly, and acai bowls look amazing (you can even customize your own!), but I was so disappointed.  :( 

Acai in the acai bowl had no taste! We ordered two small acai bowls for $8 each and both had no acai taste. The banana and granola was okay, hint of honey was nice, but I was hoping for some good acai flavor. I think perhaps they used too much strawberries in the mix because I could taste some strawberry. Maybe I went on an off day... otherwise I don't understand how this place always has a long line.
author: Iris H.

description: Wow!!! The best açai bowls I've ever tried!!! The Banyan açai bowl is simply to die for and the music and atmosphere is also great.
author: Alejandro M.

description:
I still don't understand the crazy hype around acai bowls but they are definitely good here.  One star down because it's freezing inside (I think they do it so you eat and GTFO) plus the line is almost always ridiculously long and in my opinion there are few things worth waiting for in long lines.  The reason behind it is because they make each bowl individually when you order it. My advice: get there early. 
My favorite thing about this place, though, is that they cater to just about every special diet you can imagine--which was particular important to me because I went while I was doing Whole30 and it was always such a trial to find places to eat out. They have multiple options if you are gluten-free/grain-free/Whole30/paleo/vegan, etc. They also make their own cashew milk. 
As I mentioned, I was extra high maintenance because of Whole30 so I got the Forager acai bowl with no honey, added coconut shavings, subbed almonds for granola and it was delicious. Will def go back after this cleanse so I can try it with the granola!
author: Kristina I.

description: I came here two days in a row for the few days I had in SF. Both times, I had the Islander with quinoa puffs instead of granola (added all the berries the second time - kiwi, blackberries, raspberries). I got the large size (basically a bucket) and it probably equates breakfast and lunch. The line is pretty long on weekends so expect a wait. Definitely worth it in my opinion, and lives up to the name Basik.
author: Kathy Z.

description: First time to Basik - I ordered the small ($8) Brazilian, their original acai bowl and it was pretty good but unfortunately was lacking on the smoothie base. My bowl was only 3/4th full with most of it granola and bananas. I feel like it's so embarrassing to bring it up at the place but other people around me had their small bowls filled to the brim so I felt like mine was skimped on.  It's really popular spot, with a line out the door so I think I'll be back as all the bowls looked really good.
author: Aryn C.

description:
TL;DR - I don't get it.....not worth the $ or time.

Maybe I've been spoiled by acai in Hawaii and LA.... but this place confuses me to no end (just like the inevitable line out the door)

Price:
- Expensive for what you get

Atmosphere:
- Minimalist with touches of an industrial vibe with the exposed brick. (btw I don't think there is AC here)

Now, the real issue I have. I don't mind paying ~$10 for GOOD acai, but its not here. The acai is ice-y and watered down. I know that it says its blended (I got the original) with apple juice... but I felt like I was tasting more apple than acai (also to note, most places blend acai with banana and not apple juice for a good reason). The other options were to have it blended with some type of nut milk and I don't like the texture that comes from the combo. 

Bottom line, the poor quality doesn't warrant the time nor wait associated with Basik. There's better options out there, but maybe not in this area. Try the mission.
author: Crystal Z.

description:
Sunday, 3/29. 

I:

*8:46am: Get behind about 10 ppl, waiting in line for Basik to open. Watch the Rock 'n' Roll Marathon runners go by and hear them saying,"maybe they're lined up to use the ATM" (next door to Basik). Haha no.  

*9:00am: Basik opens on the dot (their website currently says they open at 8am on Sundays but it opened at 9am per Yelp; Called prior to driving over and no one picked up so figured it opened at 9am).

*9:11am: Order the Puna as well as the Banyan Acai bowls. Each are $11 for small size. Cashier is friendly. Sit and wait for bowls. 

*9:16am: Acai bowls are delivered to our table with a smile. Time to eat. Bowls are full of quality ingredients, hence the price. Plenty of acai, fresh fruit, crunchy texture, and the right amount of sweetness. The addition of peanut butter in the Banyan is pretty special. Watch the non-stop line outside (and notice how 90% of customers look like they came from working out, including Basik staff). 

*9:28am: Leave Basik feeling healthy and satisfied. Mahalo!
author: Maya S.

description:
Line was out the door and took a good 20-30 minutes to finally place our order. Ordered a large Brasilian ($12) + added strawberries ($1?). Also want to mention that they cut their banana slices way too thick. I had to take a nibble so my ratio would stay  a little more even. After finishing, you'll feel refreshed and full. The acai blend itself isn't too strong and the acai flavor tastes a bit watered down or bland but still fills your acai cravings.

Walked down to Fort Mason with our acai bowls in hand and we got so many stares and lustful expressions from passerbys.
author: Lauren K.

description:
ACAI! 

I love acai! Not only do they offer several creations/combinations, but you can substitute for other toppings they have (like mulberries, hemp seeds, etc.)

Fresh, fast, and delicious!
author: Marissa R.

description:
Nothing hits the spot more than a delicious açaí bowl on a warm and sunny day. 

Basik Cafe absolutely nails every aspect of what you'd want in a place like this. They use fresh ingredients, have fast/friendly service, a great atmosphere and make what I think are the best açaí bowls in the city- and that's not a bold statement either (give it a try and you'll see).

First of all, if you've never had an açaí bowl before, you need to make your way over here as soon as possible. Besides being delicious, they are also incredibly healthy. How healthy you ask? Well, the main ingredient used in these bad boys is açaí berry, which comes from Açaí palm (which is a species of palm tree that originated from Brazil). Açaí berries contain a bunch of antioxidants, fibers and heart-healthy fats that are really good for your system. But I'm not a doctor, so don't hold me accountable.

So now that I'll tell you that I ordered the "Brasilian", it will actually makes sense and doesn't sound like they just gave it a random name based on a country. History! Don't you love it? No? Dang. Anyways, the Brasilian was top notch! It's basically a mix of blended açaí, apple juice toppings, granola, banana and honey (see picture). They have a diverse menu, so if you're still on the fence about getting an açaí bowl, you also have the option of getting something similar yet different, like a smoothie. We all love smoothies right?

Final verdict: Basik Cafe brings a very relaxed vibe to what is otherwise a pretty busy area. They have fast service, fresh ingredients and top notch açaí. It's the perfect place to sit down, read, write or just "grab-and-go". Enjoy!
author: Alex B.

description:
If I won the lottery, I would spend it on acai bowls from Basik on the regular.

Just kidding...or am I?

If you're okay with forking $10+ for an acai bowl, then you might as well get the best. Of the handful of places I've tried around the city, Basik has my favorite so far (though I still need to check out Bowl'd Acai). Go for the large ($14) and split it with a friend or two...or like another reviewer suggested, eat half and freeze the rest for later. That's the most economical option and you get so much more than the small.

My first bowl here was the Banyan with peanut butter, hemp hearts, honey, bee pollen, and cashew milk. It was divine. I loved the layered granola and fruit which ensures you get toppings with every bite, and the ingredients were fresh and top notch. I'm eyeing the Puna for next time.

Acai bowls are expensive, period. But if you're going to splurge, you should go with Basik because theirs are amazing, delicious, and filling.

#treatyoself
author: Valerie L.

description:
Acai bowls are the next big thing - I can feeeeeel it! Man what is it about SF and their waiting lines everywhere. Came here on a Sunday morning, and I think all the yoga studios must've decided to take a field trip here, because the line was out the door and everyone was geared ready to get into the downward dog pose. 

I got the puna bowl which was deeeeeeelicious. Expensive for the portion but it's SF -- people pay premium for their trendy foods. Downside was how small the place was. Felt like we had to pounce on a table the moment it opened up - yep kinda like savages. Also why do they spell milk like "mylk" and basic "basik"? Man if you weren't so tasty, I'd have to call you out for helping perpetuate all the rampant spelling errorz in today's society. Not k00l basik.
author: Jennie C.

description: Basik is a great spot to stop by to grab a nice breakfast or mid day snack. The prices are certainly on the higher side but all the acai bowls I've tried here have been very good. My favorites are probably the Puna and Forager.
author: Josh B.

description:
This morning I was hankering for some delicious acai. I looked over to my partner and asked her about some of the options for acai around the city and so we looked up Basik on yelp. It looked like it had gigantic and delicious bowls so we took the plunge and headed out there!

We arrived at the scene only to see a gigantic line. A line? For acai? Well we had already made the trip out here so we figured we'd wait in this gigantic line that took us about 15 minutes to go through, plus the bowls looked really good so I figured it would be worth it.

We get closer to the front and begin to see the menu. "14 dollars???". My partner was blown away at how expensive a bowl of acai could be. But again, all the signs were there to indicate that this bowl of acai would blow us away. 

So I ordered a $14 forager bowl and waited around for a seat to clear. I was hella excited.

To my disappointment the acai was bland, the bananas were not fully ripened and the strawberries tasted as though they were picked out of target. There was just no flavor. So after all of this commotion it's hard to really think of any positive experience coming out of this restaurant. The hunt for good acai in SF continues.
author: Ramie C.

description:
I was excited to try Basik after returning from my trip to Hawaii. I've only been here on weekdays so there was no wait for me. On my first visit, I was eying the Banyan, but after telling the cashier that I love the taste of acai, she recommended the Brasilian since the peanut butter in the Banyan is strong. I substituted the apple juice for almond milk, but found the Brasilian bland. All I could taste was granola. They told me they use one scoop of acai and it's unsweetened. The owner/manager let me try two different acai bases to compare. He said a lot of places over sweeten their acai base making their bowls more like ice cream, but Basik only adds honey as a topping to their acai bowls. The unsweetened acai that they use has a very subtle, slightly bitter flavor. I do prefer my acai base sweetened; he told me that Brazilians like to use a lot of guarana as a sweetener. 

I was curious to try Basik again so I visited first thing in the morning on a weekday. I wanted something I can drink while I walk to pilates so I decided on the Mayan smoothie which the cashier said was her favorite. I took it to go and was disappointed that it tasted more like minty milk. Again, I didn't taste the acai. I should've read the board more carefully and gone with a sweeter smoothie such as the drifter which is blended with strawberries. If you give them your phone number, they'll sign you up for their rewards program but you only get credits for acai bowls and not the smoothies. After two disappointing visits, I'm not sure how many stamps I'd accumulate. Maybe I should give the Banyan a try but I'm hesitant to spend another $11 here.
author: Diana B.

description: Probably another one of my acai finds on Yelp. I yelped nearby acai places and found this little place that's specially made for acai bowls and smoothies. It's fairly tiny but they do have seating inside probably for around 10 people or less. Simple menu, easy to order. They carry two sizes for their smoothies/bowls a small and a large. I got the simplest acai bowl ever which is the "Brasillian" which costed me $8 and extra fifty cents for add on chia seeds. The price is decent for what you pay for now a days for acai bowls. They didn't have much toppings, just the bananas and granola. Oh and the honey drizzle. The acai was good but only if you eat it with the granola or banana.
