I think this place isn't bad compared to other places I've tried, simple acai blended with apple juice topped with banana, honey drizzle, and granola.
author: Lisa W.

description:
Yes!!!! Finally an awesome acai bowl joint in sf that's easily accessible. Located in nob hill on Polk where parking isn't too bad. 

The only thing that will get you is that long line out the door. But that always says something about a place if there's a line right? Luckily the line moves quickly. 

The place itself is pretty small with very limited seating. 

The acai bowls are delicious and made fresh to order. They're generous with big slices of fresh fruit. The puna is my favorite so far. And not only are they delicious but they're healthy and you don't feel one bit guilty afterwards.

The workers always have smiles on their faces and are never hesitant to answer any questions. 

Prices are on the expensive side from $8-14. But you get what you pay for. 

Just scroll through the pictures. You won't need to read any reviews. I recommend everyone to try this place. 

Tip: always check their hours before you go cause it's different most of the days and there's an hour break where they close to restock.
author: Stephanie L.

description:
Had to wait 20 minutes in line, but worth it. 

Each bowl is made by hand so i was able to customize it as I wanted. Will def go back to try different toppings. 

P.S. A regular size is PLENTY big for one person, if you get a large to your face you're an animal.
author: Rachel T.

description: What a terrible experience. I came here for an açai bowl around 3:45pm. I got my bowl and began to eat. A couple minutes later, a worker told me, "Sorry, I have to ask you to leave because we need to cleanup so we can close." How rude! Where am I supposed eat my food, on the street? If that's the case, there should be signs posted on the door stating what time the dining room closes. If I had known this, I would have chosen a different place to eat, but they didn't tell me this when they took my order, my money, and my tip.
author: Christopher J.

description: Basik Café is still the best place to get an acai bowl and/or smoothie in the city. The workers here are friendly and helpful as always! During my second visit here, I had tried the Mayan Mint smoothie (açai, banana, almond butter, mint, hemp milk, cacao nibs) ($8-11), which was pretty delicious with the perfect amount of minty flavor. Next time, I want to try out the Crunch smoothie as recommended by one of the friendly workers here. Thanks Basik Café for another great experience here! I can't wait to be back.
author: Vivian L.

description: The best açaí bowl place in SF. This place will never disappoint and you will always get your order how you expect. Slightly pricey but well worth every penny spent. Loyal customer
author: Chrishel D.

description:
Located in Nob Hill across where the old Lombardi Sports used to be. The interior of Basik is very aesthetically pleasing.

I've heard good things about Basik and I was not let down. They prices are a little steep, but acai bowls are expensive everywhere. I ordered a large puna bowl, which I feel is definitely more worth it then the regular size. You can definitely share large bowl with someone else. The ingredients are very fresh. After eating the bowl, you will not feel guilty. I found out that the original Basik is from one of the islands of Hawaii. 

Awesome bowls! I have yet to try their smoothies, but I will be back!
author: Lydia H.

description: This place is expensive.  $11.00 for a small and $14.00 for a large.  My son had a small acai smoothie for $7.00. When we got there the line was around the corner.  It moved pretty fast.  We also got our order pretty fast.  Their acai bowl was ok.  Their smoothie was nothing special.  We'll probably come back here again but not anytime soon.  We will try other places for acai bowl.
author: Mark R.

description: If you're not very patient, this is not the place for you. The lines are always long especially in the middle of the day. Parking is always difficult because it's San Francisco. But, they deliver quality ingredients with their Acai bowls & if you're allergic to gluten suggest let them know - they'll suggest other ingredients for you. I tried the PUNA but without fresh bananas, w/c was amazing! This cafe had a cozy and cute ambience. It's a bit pricey but so worth it!
author: Gerlie P.

description:
Super cute place! It's small on the inside, but there's plenty of seating inside or you could stand outside! It's perfect because they come in convenient disposable cups so it's not too bad if you have to walk around or stand outside.

My boyfriend and I came here around 12 I believe and it was a tad crowded, but it didn't take us long to place our order and get our bowls. 

I like how they have a simple menu so it's not too overwhelming with all the choices like a lot of acai places. Also, if you don't like an ingredient in one of the bowls, you can replace it with something else! 

They make their bowls very aesthetic and they really pile on the toppings, which made it absolutely delicious! I got The Forager, which had cacao nibs. I was afraid it was going to be kind of bitter from it, but it actually contrasted the sweet bananas and honey and granola perfectly. 

It wasn't as good as another acai place I had in Hawaii, which was my first time too so it sets high expectations for my acai bowls. But that being said I would definitely come here again for sure!
author: Hana B.

description:
This is probably the first time I'm eating something healthy for my first meal.  Got here around 11:30am on a Sunday and there were at least 25 people ahead of me.  Waited about 30 minutes before leaving with my first ever acai bowl.

Forager (SM) $11- acai, cocoa nib, cashew mylk, banana, strawberry, cashews.  Very fresh ingredients, light, tasty, and filling.  

I have big teeth which creates pockets for little bits and pieces to nestle in.  Not sure if anyone else experiences the same problem #bigteethissues.  Make sure you check your teeth every once in a while, then continue eating.  Enjoy.
author: Linda N.

description:
There's nothing better than starting off your day with an acai bowl. I love the Islander, which has some pretty great toppings - strawberries, bananas, coconut, gojiberries, etc. If you're a peanut butter lover like me, go for the Banyan. 

Downsides of Basik: you can expect crazy lines and it's pretty pricey for a breakfast item. If you're with another person, it's worth upgrading to the large. Way bigger and small difference in price.
author: Emmy Q.

description: SO GOOD. My favorite is the Islander. The goji berries make this bowl the best. This is one of the best acai bowl places in the city. Add mulberries. Just trust me.
author: Kyle S.

description:
Wow... Wow! I have no idea what is the name of that I ordered but the only way to describe it is "wow, amazing, delicious, I would move to SF only to eat here every day"

Now the breakdown.

- this is a popular place so you might have to wait in line for a few minutes (don't panic, believe me the wait is worth it)

- it's dog friendly 

- it's an excellent healthy choice.

- it is sooo refreshing.

- if you are w someone else, I suggest you to order the large size and share... It is more than enough for two people.

I really don't have much to say because I don't want to spoil the experience but believe me.... This is a magical place. I would give 50 stars if I could.
author: Carlos R.

description:
Had to check this place out, because I was missing Nektar the juice/acai joint from back home in Southern California, but dude I was super turned off by how pompous the vibe of this place is. Granted, I went back when they still had "restocking hours", so when I got to the door to and saw they were temporarily closed mid-day on a Saturday, I was like - you need to close in the middle of brunch time because you can't prep enough in advance or have a well-trained enough staff to handle the demand? Get it together, seems pretty operationally inefficient. 

I did end up coming back from a run early enough to where the line was fairly minimal, so I decided to give it another go. Even with the small number of people in front of me, the line did not move - which is probably why there is always a line. Don't get me wrong, the Banyan bowl I got was SOLID, but not for $13 and not for the other annoyances. 

Safeway sells both Acai packets and Pitaya fruit, so for a fraction of the price and time I can make the exact same thing at home.
author: Jenna G.

description:
Yummm, I was anticipating Basik Cafe's opening for quite some time! 

Have tried both the Brasilian & Puna ($8-$14 Depending if you get a Small or Large) and liked them  - really delicious and refreshing as a snack or even a meal - the large can certainly suffice as a meal as they're quite filling.

The interior is far more spacious than I thought. There's a couple of high top tables as well as a nice bar that overlooks the busy street of Polk. I would suggest to eat your Acai right away here if you're able to. I took mine home once and the Acai does melt quite fast. 

If you love acai, fruits, smoothies, or coffee - Basik Cafe is worth a trip! Great for a casual bite/drink. Yum! And yes, they take ccs!
author: Veronica S.

description: Basik Cafe has a decent selection of acai bowls and it's one of the only, if not THE only, acai shop in the area which makes it highly sought after. The smaller sized bowls are fairly overpriced so might as well get the large for a couple of bucks more. The line is generally pretty long and you kind of have to hover for a seat but it somehow works out. I don't think that the acai is particularly flavorful and can be kind of watery compared to others I have tried. The proximity keeps me going back but I think it's a bit overhyped.
author: Salma R.

description:
Came here on a whim on one of those amazing sunny SF days. So what better way to enjoy the 75 degree weather than with an acai bowl :)   

My go-to acai bowl place in SF was always Blue Hawaiian Acai Cafe, but Basik Cafe definitely gives Blue Hawaiian a run for their money.  I especially like the variety the menu offers. I got the Islander while my friend got the Brasilian. Both topped with rather generous servings of banana and strawberries. I would recommend both!    

My only issue with Basik is that it's on the pricey side. $11 for a small acai is a bit steep & $14 for large. 

Overall, I'd definitely come back, but this won't be a go-to spot for me, probably more a treat-yo-self kinda day :)
author: Janel L.

description:
Slightly overrated, but still delicious. There's a long line, but if you mentally prepare for it before you get there, it's not that bad. 

They have 6 main acai bowls on their menu but you can substitute different things in them if you don't like something! I got the islander with almond milk instead of hemp milk. There are also a lot of substitutes for granola if you don't like granola. They have smoothies and coffee too, but I haven't tried either. 

I love that this place is dairy free! The large is only $3 more than the small, so I got the large and saved some in my freezer for later. They're pretty generous with toppings and it does really keep you full. 

It's a pretty small place but there are tables and seats if you want to stay there and eat. You can take it and walk over to chestnut to eat your acai bowl whilst shopping in the marina. 

Be sure to wear your lulu lemon leggings to fit in.
author: Elizabeth K.

description: Review only for the "islander" acai bowl! It's definitely so much better than judalishes ! It has so much more fruits and the acai taste so much fresher! The small can be a meal itself! Super filling and good! Definitely will come back again to try the puna!
author: Shirley G.

description: Best acai bowl I have had. Will def be going back. Line was long, but wait was ok after ordering.
author: Li N.

description:
Premium acai bowl breakfast spot! I came on a weekday for brunch to avoid the line, and was met with customized service and only a short wait. The trick is to come here in pairs so that you can split the large sized ($14) bowls that are big enough to serve 2. 

Banyan bowl 4/5: great ratio of granola to fresh fruit to acai berry smoothie. The layers of granola sandwiched deep in the cup came as a crunchy surprise; oftentimes there's far too much smoothie that dilutes the crunch in every bite. I liked the uniqueness of the toppings with more than just honey and almonds but also bee pollen and hemp hearts. I didn't know what to expect of this combination, but it was delicious! It could have used a little more peanut butter flavor thigh for a more nutty savory flavor instead of just the sweetness of the fruits. 

Would I come back? Definitely, next time I'll be sure to try some of the other flavors especially the seasonal ones.
author: Kathy T.

description: I love love love this place. The puna is great and the acai is like a smoothie texture and it is amazing!
author: Tina L.

description: looooove this place!!! best thing to be created honestly 10/10 would recommend. the large size is definitely way more worth it than the regular. Go big or go home right??
author: Jodie X.

description: Really, really great acai bowl - I highly recommend for a meal that feels substantial but fresh. The 1 star deduction stems from the fact that their hours are quite limited (I only made it on my THIRD attempt since it's nearly impossible for me to swing anything before 4pm on any given day). To top it off, I've wandered past on the weekends and there's often a line outside. Now I realize that's probably a result of how small the venue is because they're quite speedy at prepping the bowls and you can take them to go. Basically, I'd recommend going and even waiting in line, but 3 separate attempts like mine are probably overkill - I've had similar acai bowls elsewhere.
author: Ana M.

description:
$11 for a small / $14 for a large 

Came here on a sunny Sunday afternoon wanting to be healthy. There's no better way than joining everyone wearing their workout clothes to eat a refreshing Acai bowl. Although the line was out the door, the wait wasn't that bad, maybe 15-20 minutes tops. As we waited I got tricked by my boyfriend to get a large so that we could share and he could try as well. He said that the small was too small. However, the cups are pretty wide so a small is definitely enough for one person, unless you're starving or sharing - then I would recommend the large. I ordered the Islander, which was super good! The only thing I did not like was the goji berries. I think next time i'll try to Puna because there are blueberries instead of goji berries. 

Would definitely recommend!
author: Michelle C.

description: Fresh, tasty, healthy BUT pricey! I've tried different acai bowls and they're all awesome! I usually go to the cafe around odd times so that I don't have to wait in a long line. I'm knocking a star off for the high price. Overall, great place!
author: Noor S.

description:
The first time we tried acai was in Lala land.  My daughter loves acai ever since it got introduced to us by my little sister.  We were already in the city, driving around and trying new different places.  Glad we found this place.  As usual, parking was hard but got lucky finding a spot right across the street.  Today was another good day for healthy snacks and definitely have to come back here.  It was pretty expensive as well but the look on my daughter's face was priceless....happiness and satisfaction!
I love the granola in the middle and all around the bowl.  Banana's was just right and strawberries were
sweet as candy!  Next time we're around the city we have to try other acai flavors.

Service-4
Acai-5
Cleanliness-5
Parking-3
Price-4
author: Coco C.

description: My weekends wouldn't be as great as they are without a stop at Basik Cafe. Best acai bowls I've ever had.
author: Giulia C.

description: This is acai bowl heaven. Their portions are huge and come with all different kinds of toppings. You can get fresh fruit, granola, honey, coconut shavings, etc on it. Theres some seating but it's a fairly small place. There's also constantly a line out the door on weekends but weekdays are not bad. If I lived in San Francisco I would be here all the time but I will definitely be stopping by the next time I'm in the area.
author: Angela Y.

description:
I love the bowls but the customer service was horrendous this last time. 

When visiting San Francisco I would make this one of my must go to spots. However this last time, I ordered the same Banyan Bowl I always get and they forgot to include granola.  I believe this was because the woman before me asked for no granola. After a few bites I noticed this was missing. I asked them to make me a new bowl with the granola on top and mixed in (per usual). They refused to do so and instead added granola to the top. 

Paying $14 for an Acaii bowl, I expect it to be exactly what I ask for. I thought this was extremely poor customer service and has since made me question going back to this establishment.
author: Laura S.

description:
A really nice, new, modern, interesting place that tries to bring something really popular from Hawaii. I was just walking around Nob Hill and was intrigued by the decor and design of the place. Came in, looked at the nice & simple menu, and ordered a smoothie. 

+ The Drifter
Made with açai, almond milk, strawberries, bananas, cacao, and honey, the Drifter smoothie was creamy and refreshing. I could clearly taste the freshness of the fruits and the cacao gave the smoothie an added delicate taste and sweetness. The ingredients were well-balanced, a little too chocolatey to my taste, but still good nonetheless. Maybe I could ask for a little less raw cocoa next time! I felt pretty full after I finished my drink.

Everything on the menu at Basik Cafe is somewhat pricey. For $7.00 (for a smoothie, $11.00 for an açai bowl), you do get fresh and quality fruits and ingredients. I shall try their bowl next time, and you should to. Much healthy, it is.
author: Alex L.

description:
Basik bowls are slurpees for healthnuts.  The fruity garnish on top sanctifies the sugary content below.  We stop by whenever there isn't a line.  I occasionally live in denial--It must be good for you if it's organic, right?  At least it's lower fat than brownies.

5 stars for quality and 4 stars for price and hours.  They're not predictably open since they often run out of acai (c'mon guys...it's the ONE KEY ingredient and it's FROZEN).  Also, their assembly line is very slow.  If they can improve operational efficiencies, it would decrease the dreaded queue to order and the wait after placing the order.

BTW: I'm not a healthnut but the dress code for everyone else is spandex or Lululemon.
author: Amy J.

description: I've been here a few times now, and can say that Basik is one of my favorite places in the city to grab an acai bowl. There are long lines on weekends, but the wait is well worth it. I've tried a few bowls on the menu, and have concluded that you should never get a bowl with goji berry in it: the texture of hard dehydrated and the fact that it gets stuck to your back teeth is not very pleasant. The brasilian however, is quite tasty. Would definitely recommend it if it's your first time.
author: Austin W.

description: Had the puna. It was delicious and the large is a good amount to split with two even though I can see myself eating one all by myself. I felt so healthy and it tasted so refreshing. The granola was delicious too! Though I wonder how "healthy" it really is... or mostly how many calories from the sugar and granola. But, would come here again! Even if it is on the pricey side. Decor is cute and simple. I dig it.
author: Josie W.

description: Pretty good acai, nothing spectacular. 3 stars because the seating is very uncomfortable. I came here hoping I could pull out my laptop and work for awhile- no way. Metal stools on a tiny ledge by the window just barely allow you to wharf down your acai and leave. Not a very pleasant experience
author: Paola M.

description: Trying to get healthy and this place was fast and convenient. Nice staff. My Kona smoothie was a little more liquidy than I prefer but I'm willing to try another smoothie and perhaps an acai bowl. Clean and friendly and on my way to work. I'll be back!
author: Marilyn N.

description:
My stomach loves this place ; my wallet does not. 

REALLY delicious Acai bowls (the smoothies are good too... But the bowls are next level). 
My only complaints are: 
1) Price - however, these bowls keep you full for hourzzz
2) The hours - for those of us who commute out of the city each day, 8-4 means it's near impossible to enjoy these tasty bowls during the week :(. Extending to open a bit earlier or close in the early evening would be amazing.
author: Catherine S.

description:
I never thought I'd be the person who would stand  in line 20 mins for an...wait for it....Acai bowl. 
But that's what living in SF does to you.
People wait 20+ mins and pay $14 for a 24oz of Acai topped with honey, almonds, granola and some bee pollen situation. And people/ I Love it. 
The large was huge  and filled me up for hours. 
I packed the rest of it home for dessert after dinner. 
Extra love for it since it's from Hawaii- my 2nd home. Literally. 
Prepare to wait in line, especially on the weekends, but absolutely a yummy alternative to a pedestrian smoothie or ice cream
author: Jocelyn L.

description: I had my first acai bowl here. I'm glad it was this place. I had the Forager for the cacao nibbles. The names of the choices makes you feel like your in the tropics. Nothing was too sweet. Overall it was delicious, I would come here again if I was in the area. They need to stay open longer though.
author: Jaime F.

description:
Great deal but not worth the wait of 30 mins.
The size of the acai bowls are good I wish they moved faster. It is the Hawaiian style of service slow slow slow!!
author: Alison W.

description: Acai bowls to your liking! FTW! Haha, I know that was cheesy. The line was out the door. People were waiting to get their acai bowls to eat for the summer. There is some seating, but not as much. Some sat inside and finished their acai bowls. Some took it and walked out with it. I suppose it was nice stroll outside since the weather was warm. Absolutely love this place! It does remind me a bit of Hawaii. The menu is quite simple, so you won't get confused. Pick an acai bowl to your choosing and liking. Pay at the window and wait for your name to be called with your acai bowl. Prepare yourself to be refreshed! :)
author: Jennifer G.H. W.

description: The acai bowls are phenomenal. Definitely a place to try if you're looking for a great place to have breakfast.
author: Christabelle B.

description: The bowls here are so good! Biggest one I've ever had. Great service and came out super fast. Must try!
author: Megan W.

description: My favorite acai bowl place. There will be a wait the only way around that is postmates. I enjoy the Banayan with added strawberries. Had others but so far that is my favorite. Although, on the more expensive side I find it worth the money if you want something good for you and refreshing. I want to explore more options off their menu. Not your average Acai bowl.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Place is filled with white girls and a few of their boyfriends who got dragged along. Line is long but the end product is quite decent. The service is fast. I got the smoothie. Good, fresh, not mind blowing.

They should put one of these in the marina so I don't have to uber / drive just a fruit bowl.
author: Peter T.

description: Trying Acai for the first time and Aloha Basik had totally nailed it!!
author: Teresa C.

description: So I'll preface this review by saying I come here a lot, about 1x per week. Normally the experience is 5 stars, except for the wait. Today was different - the staff inside were talking loudly and dropping f-bombs which I'm sure the mom with her little kids didn't like, the fruit was cut poorly (strawberry chunks so big they didn't fit in my mouth) and haphazardly arranged, and they put on way too much honey.  I'll end up going back because it is usually very good, but today was a bad experience.
author: B T.

description: The large is gigantic, would definitely recommend it since it's only $3 more. I like this place! It's clean, healthy, and they have wifi. Definitely going to stop in often after my morning runs--acai bowls are a good way to defeat my cravings for slightly less nutritious post-run foods (i.e. chips and burgers), even though I cringe a little at paying $14 for fruit.
author: Ava H.

description: I popped my acai bowl cherry here at Basik. The line was out the door when I came around 10 AM on a Sunday. The line moved pretty quickly and the bowls came out very fast. I got a small Puna bowl for $12. A little pricey but it was very filling. I enjoyed the tartness of the acai and the fresh fruit and granola provide a lot of different textures. I'm not hooked on the acai bowl craze yet but my first experience got me wanting to try more.
author: Mymy N.

description: Love the acai, the Hawaiian vibes, the music, decor.. Everything!!! Worth the wait. I got the is islander and LOVEEEDD it. Only suggestion is add a medium sized bowl!! Small is too small and large is too big.
author: Kaitlyn V.

description:
This place closes at 4 on weekdays, so I can only make it on weekends. So how does this place compare to the many other Acai places in SF now? 
For starters, its a bit cheaper. its 12 bucks for a large, which is LARGE. I've seen Acai bowls go over 15 bucks easily (and for a smaller portion than you would get here). 

Also, being Brazilian and having had my first acai there, I constantly compare it to how its done there. This means just the original acai, with a thicker sorbet consistency ( most of the ones we find in SF are almost smoothie-like)  blended with guarana, although I'm not sure they  blend it with guarana here, and served with honey, bananas, and granola. They have a bowl here that fits that description and it is appropriately named the "Brasilian" (spelled with an S, so bonus points for that) and is what I got. It was really, really, good and I could immediately understand why this place always has such a long line (i've walked by a couple times before and was deterred by the line). Not too sweet, or too tangy, great consistency, and huge portion. 

The great thing about this place is that it does acai the original way (or at least how the original is in my mind), but they also have many variations of acai bowls and topping choices. In addition to bowls, they also have smoothies. Sort of like a one stop shop for all things acai. Its a small place with limited seating and the seemingly intimidating line out the door goes pretty quickly. I took mine to go and headed up polk towards Fort Mason by the water. 

This place and Bowl'd Acai are my favorites in SF thus far.
author: Thielson D.

description: I've been going here every Sunday morning for the past few months. The cafe opens at 9 on Sundays and there can be a pretty long line. I'm about a 10 min walk away and I like to get there a few minutes before it opens. Their acai bowls are amazing! The have lots of different types - ranging from standard to way out there. My favorite is the islander and I love trying the seasonal add-ons available. The fruit is always fresh, acai has a good texture with flavor but not too sweet, perfect amount of granola, and nice presentation. I've heard a lot of great things about their smoothies, which I haven't tried yet. They also have warm options for winter. I tried the chia/quinoa with berry compote. This was also super good. This place has amazing acai bowls and I would totally suggest it!
author: Annabel W.

description:
I remember the first time I had an Acai bowl in Hawaii. It was 2012, 90 degrees, and humid outside. I took a bite of the bowl, and immediately floated away into a blueberry/acai/strawberry heaven.

Fast forward 3 years - I stumbled upon Basik Cafe only a few blocks away from my house. Unfortunately, there was a 1 hour wait... so I decided to come back another time.

Finally tried it last week - per the suggestion of another customer, I got the islander.
The acai bowl was good, the fruit was fresh, the granola crunchy - my only issue was the price. Seems a little steep for a smoothie bowl, but I know the ingredients are expensive and high quality, so probably worth it for a treat to my self every now and then.

Note - the large size is only a few bucks more expensive than the small, and double the size. If you're a big eater, or plan on sharing your acai bowl with someone else, definitely get the large for a bigger bang for your buck.
author: Michelle L.

description: Great acai bowls! I had the large islander but I would recommend getting the large size for 2 people. Their large portion is huge, making it ideal for sharing. For the toppings, I had granola, banana, strawberries, goji berries and coconuts; which are the toppings for the islander but next time, I would customize it. I loved every bite of my super-size acai bowl and I want to try the other bowls on their menu. I'm certain that they'll all be delicious! Next time when I crave an acai bowl in SF, I'll go out of my way to get it from here.
author: Burcu D.

description: I got the forager bowl and I can say it was one the most refreshing meals I've ever had! It was SO fresh and delicious on a warm summer morning.
author: Erin E.

description:
So happy I made the trek over to Basik Cafe when I was in San Francisco for the day. Anyone knows that I am a HUGE fan of Acai Bowls/Smoothies/Superfoods (I often make my own smoothies in the morning for breakfast and do homemade acai bowls with homemade nut butters, etc.) and this place really blew me away!

The place is VERY simple - not a lot of seating, some simple lighting. A refreshing feel though, for sure. 

I tried the BANYAN bowl after asking the store lead what the most popular acai bowl was. It came with granola, honey, bananas, and was blended with peanut butter. It was absolutely DELICIOUS! Great texture, the honey drizzle was the perfect touch of sweetness, the granola was not too crunchy but not too soft, it is topped with almonds which adds the perfect extra crunch, and the base itself was great (esp. with the touch of peanut butter).

Overall, the meal felt satisfying and refreshing - not too heavy. I was a little iffy about paying $11 for a small acai bowl, but hey... they're based out of Kona and so you're paying for some authentic stuff here.

OVERALL VERDICT: I'm 100% addicted to acai bowls (would definitely say they are in my top 3 foods of all times) and I have nothing but great things to say about this spot!
author: Roopa S.

description: I ABSOLUTELY LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS PLACE. Basik makes the best acai bowl I have ever tried. Although its on the pricey side ($11 for a small and $14 for a large) their ingredients and great tasting acai bowl is sooooo worth it. I would definitely recommend trying the islander if you've never tried an acai bowl before. It's a very small place but gives off cute Hawaiian vibes. I've read that the owner is from Hawaii, and the taste of the bowls definitely backs that up. It really tastes like the acai bowls i've tried in Hawaii. I'd definitely recommend that you try this place at least once! You won't regret it!!
author: Kelly S.

description: Acai bowls are usually a splurge when it comes to breakfast, but going to Basik and getting their delicious (and beautiful!) bowls is totally worth the time, price, and wait.  Having had some incredible acai bowls in Hawaii and loving my acai bowl from Blue Hawaii by the Embarcadero, Basik had a lot to live up to. That being said, after 10 minutes of serious indecisiveness, I went a little wild and got their season bowl called the Dawn Patrol, which was acai w/ almond milk, granola, peaches, blueberries, raspberries, mulberries, bee pollen, honey.  SO ono-licious! My husband had the Islander and loved the gojiberries and incredible granola that came with it.  All in all, we both absolutely loved our bowls and will definitely be back!
author: Lisa I.

description:
Pretty yummy. I got the Brasilian which is simply a blend of açaí and apple topped with banana and granola with honey drizzle.
 
I thought the blend was slightlt too runny for my taste but the flavors were good. I liked the crispy granola texture and the banana was fresh. The honey brought eveything together nicely. The small was $8.

Going to try the others real soon.
author: Heejin L.

description:
The smoothies and acai bowls are seriously delicious. You can't go wrong, the crunch smoothie is my personal favorite but I've loved everything I've had here. Prices are super reasonable as well. Staff is friendly and even with the line things move pretty quickly.

The only thing I'd change is their hours. They don't open until 8am which is such a bummer. I really wish they'd open at 7am so more people (myself included) could get breakfast there before work. 8am is too late as a lot of people need to be in the office by 8 if not earlier.
author: Lizzy U.

description: Great spot for Acai Bowls! The forager is a favourite of mine. I usually substitute their granola with pumpkin seeds. They have a great variety of options and add ons! Will be back soon!
author: Ghazal S.

description:
Pretty good. 

I ordered the Islander as it was recommended for first timers. I think I prefer when the acai is blended with apple juice, for a sweeter taste, so I wouldn't recommend the Islander (blended with hemp milk) if you want something sweeter. I loved the finely flaked coconut and it's hard to mess up sliced bananas and strawberries. 

The people are friendly, bowls come out quickly. I'd come back to try a different combination!
author: Lena H.

description:
Love this place! I usually get my acai bowls from Judahlicious (outer sunset) but during my last visit I was disappointed with a super icy blend with only a few bananas. 
On the other hand, the acai at Basik is flavorful and has a good texture. There are a lot of toppings also. Definitely pricey but the large can be eaten in two different sittings!
author: Breanna T.

description:
The best Acai bowl in the city. 

Basik infuses all of their food with good vibes.

Their space is clean with natural light, their menu is easy to navigate and each one of their remarkable acai bowls is packed full of quality and fresh ingredients.

I've eaten a number of acai bowls in the city now and Basik was by far the most memorable. Presentation wise - their bowls (the small is huge and the large is unreal) are masterpieces with stunning vivid natural radiance from their carefully chosen fruit and toppings - such as pomegranate seeds or bee pollen.

You can't go wrong with any of their bowls or smoothies at Basik Cafe and I appreciate that they use milk sources such as hemp or cashew milk - rather than the soy milk that you often find at other Acai places in the city. You can also tell that the honey that they use is well sourced.

I highly recommend hitting up Basik Cafe on a lovely day. It will nourish your soul and your stomach with a burst of natural sweetness.

Trust.
author: Jessica T.

description:
** my new brunch spot !!! **
D E L I C I O U S....but kinda pricey. but eh! 
Get the large ($11-$14) - it's a better bang for your buck(s) in my opinion :)

Super fresh and great balance of flavors. You can taste the quality. They also incorporate the granola into the Acai nicely. It's swirled into the middle and not just stacked. 

** They take breaks ( rightfully so! ) in the middle of the day, so if theres a line...don't worry it will move along!

I tried the Kailauea --- totally wrong spelling, sorry! It had a mango base along with the banana/strawberry base that all bowls have. The goji berries were SO good on top. yum yum yum.

My friend got the Banyan - so indulgent!! Great cocoa flavor, perfect sweetness! My homegirl is from Hawaii and she even thought that these bowls were legit :)

I can't wait to try ALL the bowls and ALL the smoothies :P
author: Selina W.

description:
I don't think I've ever enjoyed something so healthy in my life! Usually something healthy for me screams "BLAND AF!" But its definitely not the case here. 

Came here the first time since it was near my iphone repair place. and got the Forager. Second time was because I was close to Northbeach, and wanted to introduce this to my friend, and we share the Banyan.

Forager - So delicious. The granola they use is just impeccable. It's crunchy to perfection, and it's not hard like most granola. It's like a fluffy, friendly to your teeth crunchy. And they won't stick to your molars. The flavors blended well together. 

Banyan - Who isn't intrigued by the been pollen in the listed ingredient? That was the major thing that attracted me, but my friend wanted it for the peanut butter. Overall, still delicious, but I prefer the Forager more. The major reason as to why is because almonds are hard. I feel like an old grandma complaining how the food is hard now. I swear I'm still in my early 20's. 


Oh yes, the large is twice the size of the regular and it's only $3-4 more. I don't know why but I won't question it. i feel like it wouldn't be worth it to get a regular (quite pricey really) for approx $10-12. It's great to get a large if you have a buddy to share it with.
author: Harriet W.

description:
Basik is not so basic. My first Acai bowl experience and I can officially say I'm hooked. Given the hefty price tag for a small ($11) I will have to limit my intake but goodness that bowl was delicious. The ingredients were fresh and the toppings were unique and filling. It feels amazing eating something so healthy and delicious. 

The shop is small and quaint with the perfect amount of room to sit down and enjoy breakfast. Don't expect to sit here for too long to get work done because they do not offer WIFi.
author: Rita M.

description:
Firstly, there is no doubt that the acai bowls are delicious, the toppings are fresh and quality is consistent.

I am very unimpressed with the company's lack of environmental concern.  I am continually turned away or "given slack" for bringing my own container to put the acai in!  The container is clean, and the opening is wide enough to fit the contents.  So simple.  So easy.  Why is this a big deal???  

For the sake of aesthetics and ease of an assembly-line?  That's what it seems to come down to.

As a customer who goes out of her way to bring her own container, obviously I don't care about how my acai bowl looks.  I'm not planning to Instagram this glorious moment. 

With all the environmental problems in the world, a practice this simple should be common place.  And as a company that boasts as hailing from Hawaii, I would think they would would be more concerned about the sheer amount of waste they produce daily.  

After many embarrassing attempts, I tried to persevere and keep a positive attitude about it all.  I even spoke with the owner Derek about it.  He was extremely nice and assured me that whatever container I brought would be served in.  

But then, a few months have passed and ONCE AGAIN, it was a "problem" that I brought my own container.  Which is just evidence to me that it is formally against protocol to allow customers to bring their own container.  

And that is pretty lame. 

Obviously this is something I care about, and feel it is worth pointing out.
author: Kyle Q.

description: By far the best acai bowls in the city and a great way to start off any weekend. I am a huge fan of the Banyan, which was a mix of acai, peanut butter, almond milk, bee pollen, granola, and all kinds of other goodness. They definitely don't skimp and you get a very wide variety of toppings to choose from. Make sure to get the large (at $14 it is not cheap but it is extremely filling). It is a large meal in and of itself, so learn from my mistakes and don't get a large acai bowl all for yourself right before going to brunch. The small ($11) is still quite a hefty bowl but it still leaves me wanting more and doesn't seem as quite of a good deal. I just wish this place were closer to home!
author: Sally C.

description:
My sister convinced me to try this place, as she lived in Hawaii for 4 years and is obsessed with acai bowls! When I told her this place had opened down the street from me, she told me I HAD to go!

I am so glad this place is less than 2 blocks from my house! Now I understand why everyone loves acai bowls so much. They have fresh fruit, granola, honey, and other toppings and they are all made to order! I've only had the Brazilian bowl (which is incredible) but I am looking forward to trying more! My husband got one of their smoothies which are perfect for on-the-go.

If you go during the week it won't be a problem. However you may deal with lines on the weekends. It's worth the wait though. The staff is very friendly and they are fast so you won't have to wait long for your order. The space is small but there are a few places to sit if it isn't too crowded! This place also has a touch of Aloha, which I love!
author: Chisholm T.

description:
Basik Cafe is my favorite place to pick up an Acai bowl in the city.  I almost didn't want to write this review so it won't get overcrowded but it already has so I'll just write it now.  I seriously don't know how this stuff is soooooo good but it is. There are two sizes you can get but I always get the biggest because it basically becomes a meal if you do that.  All the toppings are really good and the place itself is very clean and bright.  

The only downfall to this place is its location because parking can be a pain in the butt!  Also, if you don't want to wait in line I suggest either going right when it opens or wait until the afternoon.
author: Krystal L.

description:
Best acai bowls hands down! Completely addictive and while they are $11/each, I would say it substitutes for a light lunch. 

I just got back from Hawaii and was excited to try the best local Hawaiian bowls.  None of the acai bowls even compared to Basik! 

My go to is the Puna bowl! Fresh, delicious, the best! The fruit is always ripe and the acai is smooth, fresh and tasty. 

The line can be long (30+ minutes) on sunny weekend days 10am-1pm so try to go off peak hours.
author: Britney R.

description: Huge acai bowls for a decent price - these are packed full of flavor and healthy stuff. We went when there was 0 line but the food comes out quickly and beautifully. #foodp*rn
author: Shelley K.

description: Super fresh bowls, friendly staff and extremely accommodating. Added blueberries and strawberries to my Brazillian bowl for free and it was delicious!
author: Sam M.

description:
Yayyyyyyyyy. 

It's definitely an expensive meal-substitute, however I believe it's worth it. They really give you a hearty portion packed with all sorts of whole foods
author: Grace C.

description:
I don't know where acai has been all my life but I've picked up on it big time recently and love it.  It's great to see a place like Basik Cafe come in and serve it in unique and satisfying ways.  I ordered the Puna and the fruit and strawberries in there were excellent.  My wife had the banyan and the peanut butter was a nice addition.

We're definitely coming back!
author: Blake B.

description:
So fresh and so good, good. Finally got over to Basik last weekend to try their bowls, which definitely lived up to the hype. Loved the optional addition of fresh blackberries or raspberries -- not toppings I usually see on acai bowls. I got the Puna and added kale, which was delicious. 

If you arrive and see a line out the door, don't freak out; it moves quickly.

My only complaint is the 1 p.m. closing time on Sundays. Why?! But you know a place is good when a customer shows up at 12:58 p.m. and is visibly angry that she missed out on the day's bowls. I also wish there was a size between the regular and enormous, but I'll be back for more either way.
author: Elena K.

description:
The owners are from the Big Island and I'm really happy that they decided to start this venture in San Francisco.  Definitely give this place a try if you are ever in the neighborhood.  It's on the pricey side, but well worth the price.  I usually get the large bowls and break it out into two meals.  I'm rooting for you Basik!!  

My only tip is to find a way to speed up production during the peak times.  Something about waiting 15 minutes for an acai bowl that gets people a bit peeved.  After all, this is a city and you're no longer on Island time.
author: Kelvin W.

description:
So glad they have made their way to SF from Hawaii! The acai bowls are amazing, definitely the best in the city.
The portions are really big and all of the ingredients taste fresh. If there is a line, don't worry it moves fast. 
The location is really cute, but small. Next time I would get a large bowl and split it with someone!
author: Alisha K.

description:
Quality ingredients in delicious acai bowls. I like that they offer hemp milk and almond milk as an alternative to soy milk. 

I've tried the islander, puna and forager; puna is my favorite. 

Awesome friendly staff that always produce a consistently good product despite the crowds. Be advised, there is almost always a long line, and they close for an hour in the early afternoon.
author: Siobhan L.

description:
Yum. Expensive but super high quality and nice portions. I'm glad I don't live closer, it would be dangerous.

It did take them awhile to make and I had an appointment to run to, but they were awesome and held my bowl in the fridge until I came back 10-15 min later.
author: Hanna L.

description: Dude. 14$? Who lines up for a bowl of acai that costs $14? And a service change (not listed on the menu) for large orders? You go ahead. Me? No.
author: matthew d.

description:
WOW. Best acai bowls in San Francisco--period. 

Staff are super friendly and definitely have that local vibe going on. Coming from Hawaii, it was extremely surprising and pleasant to see that both the acai bowls and staff bring back the local flavor of Hawaii to SF. Acai bowls are comparable to the  Mana Bowls in Honolulu from Diamond Head Health Bar :)

Had the Kilauea acai bowl that came with goji berries, honey pollen, strawberries, and granola. Acai had a super smooth flavor and creamy consistency with a good amount of toppings mixed in. 

As I said before, staff are extremely friendly and really make you feel like you're at home! Make sure you check out the super cool map of the Big Island located in the back near the restrooms. Bowls are pretty pricey, but considering the quality of the bowl, I am always willing to pay $11 for the bowl. 

Hoping that they will expand store hours but will definitely return again.
author: Jayne Y.

description: Waiting in a long line for a $10-$14 acai bowl is indeed #basic, but... it's worth it. The bowls are packed with lots of acai and fresh fruits and substantial enough for a meal.
author: Sloane F.

description:
The name is unfortunate, but the acai bowls are delicious! My favorite is the banyan bowl: peanut butter, bananas, acai, granola, almonds, bee pollen (not something I ever thought I would be eating)...it's delicious. 

Everything is extremely fresh and tasty and the service is great. On a weekend morning there's normally a line out the door of people waiting for their acai bowls in their athleisure wear. I am often one of them.

Yes, it's pricey and a little cliche, but it's so so so good.
author: Ana D.

description: If you've ever had really great acai, this isn't the place for you. However, if this is your first time trying it, you wouldn't know that  it's absolutely subpar. The acai base is bland and flavorless, the bananas were not yet ripe, and the toppings were scarce (either that or also just flavorless). Overall, the bowl tasted very bland (and unlike other sweet and filling Brazilian acai bowls I've had elsewhere). And once you tally in the expensive price ($14 for a large bowl - what?)...it just ends up being over-priced, mediocre acai.
author: Isabel T.

description:
The most bizarre people work here. They wear unknown brands like Billabong and Quicksilver. They rock island wear and bump Marley tunes. I don't know how to react. However, their cliental is strictly outfitted in Lulu. Fewf! I feel at home instantly.

Also, please note, it's mandatory to workout before you step inside. You must sweat before you eat healthy food. The latter is NOT enough! Learn from my mistake!

Oh, the food? Incredible!
author: Kendra C.

description: There are not many acai places as I would like in SF but Basik is great! So healthy and refreshing and so fresh. Can't go wrong with any of the bowls. Also, there usually is a line but it moves fairly quick.
author: Christine T.

description:
Went large based on other reviews and thank goodness. Huge portion kept me satisfed from breakfast time until mid afternoon. And maybe it's the placebo effect or the boasted "all the amino acids and nutrients you need" properties of the acai bowls but I felt like I started a long day of studying on the right note.
Being $14 for a large, it's not cheap but would definitely stop by in the near future.
Not much of a wait at 8.30am on a Saturday.
author: Tina K.

description: Loved the Açai bowl. Got the Puna and Forager. Small is good for one person - large is too big so please be ready to share!
author: Dimple N.

description: It usually takes about 10-20 minutes to get your acai bowl, plus waiting in line on some days. Definitely worth the wait!!
author: Anna W.

description:
The most delicious breakfast you could ever get! Upgrade the large, because it's totally worth it (for the small price difference, the size difference is much larger).

Only 4*s because while it's great, it's not worth the crazy wait! Order it to pick up, or Postmate it. Or even go to Trader Joe's, buy all the same ingredients, and make it at home.
author: Kerry G.

description: It's my Saturday mid-morning tradition -- I will wait in any long line to get me some Basik acai bowls! Love the quality of the ingredients and their ability to customize your order. I have nothing but excellent things to say about Basik.
author: Holland M.

description: Small place yet what do you expect when they really only serve one thing. The Islander Acai Bowl was amazing. I ordered it without the coconut. It was probably one of the best I've had in San Francisco.
author: Michael F.

description:
This is some of the best acai around, hands down. Ironically, it was also one of the earlier acai bowls we'd ever had, so we didn't fully appreciate how good it was until trying many others. The price tag is high, but if you get the large, you'll be full for hours and maybe only need a light snack before dinner, no lunch. $14 for two meals isn't bad! While the price tag is hefty compared to other acai bowls, they're really delivering you quality ingredients and massive servings. This is their second shop, their first was on the Big Island in Hawaii.

We mostly had the islander each time we went - a blend of acai and housemade hemp milk, topped with strawberries, bananas, goji berries, organic coconut shavings and Hawaiian honey. This stuff is good! Sweet without being too sweet and a perfect blend of flavors that come together nicely. The acai is also the perfect consistency of just a bit thicker than a smoothie, perfect to eat with a spoon. You can choose to get the granola gluten free or not.

The acai bowls are completely dairy free (as many are), and they also have a long list of smoothies if that's more your speed. I believe they're also selling Kona coffee now. Service is very friendly. Seating is limited, but it's good if you go with a friend, have them order and snag a seat whenever one becomes available. My mom and sister were in town for a long weekend, and asked to go back to this place more than once - it's that good. The line is out the door, even on weekday mornings, which should be a sign on just how good it is!
author: Jackie W.

description: Great smoothies, but DAMN the line was probably 10 deep, around noon on a Saturday and it took 30+minutes to get my smoothie.
author: Amanda L.

description: I love getting Acai bowls from here. The taste is really good. Location is great. Service was outstanding. They use real fresh fruits. Healthy and yummy!
author: Jiraporn S.

description: This is the best acai bowl I have ever had! I got the Islander and added raspberries. It was so fresh and the perfect way to start another day in San Francisco! I highly recommend making a stop here!
author: Olivia C.

description:
HUGE fan on this new Polk Street addition!

My Fav: The Banyan! Love the Peanut Butter.

It's on the expensive side so I try to order the Large, eat half and put the rest in the freezer.

Tip: Join their frequent buyer program! Ask at the register :)

Aloha!
author: Michelle K.

description: Hands-down best Acai I've ever had! Worth the wait, perfect on a warm day. Pricey, but acai itself is pricey and they use good, fresh, quality ingredients. Highly recommend the Hulailala if they have it (blueberries, kiwi, almonds, pomegranate seeds, granola and honey).
author: Marissa B.

description:
Interesting decor and a little on the pricey side (should be rated $$$ if measured on a relative log scale), but for uniqueness and overall healthiness, a clear winner.  

The feature here is the acai berry, mixed with other combinations of ingredients which vary in texture, color, taste, and health benefit. The result is a color and taste explosion which you might not be able to finish in one sitting. The Kona coffee is also something I didn't expect, and was pleasantly surprised. I would imagine the place gets packed so I hope they will have outdoor seating at some point. 

-Great for after the gym as most of the ingredients are essential for effective recovery. 
-Sometimes they sell out and close up early, so keep that in mind when planning a visit!
author: Ben K.

description: Didn't think I would fly cross country to try an acai bowl but I'm glad I did! Well I didn't purposely fly cross country for this. I wanted something light before a big dinner so since I was in the neighborhood, I decided to try the acai bowls. It was not disappointing at all. Each bowl is blended with an acai base into a sorbet consistency and then topped off with various nuts, fruits and granola. A filling and healthy snack in the midday!
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Basik has the best bang for the buck acai bowls that I know of. Really good ingredients and well made.
author: Christopher F.

description:
I was sooooo excited to finally have a chance to try out this place! First acai bowl ever and it was definitely an amazing first impression! Literally the perfect amount of honey to fruit to nuts to acai blend. I got the forager which has cacao nibs and acai is blended with cocoa powder and cashew mylk. 
They even had little samples of their more exotic ingredients on the counters! Only complaint is it's a tad in the expensive side but that's the price you pay for good food and a healthy life!
author: Gina I.

description:
Really good, but $11 for a small?? I would have taken less quantity for less price. If there were a size smaller than small.... 

The Banyan was delicious and I had trouble deciding on a flavor. The peanut butter made the blend unique. Loved the texture of the acai bowl. 

You're definitely going to eat lunch so at that price point it's not economical to get this every day... same with pressed juices.
author: Jeanne C.

description:
Basik was basic. I waited in line for 20 min for this acai bowl and paid $12, it was aiiight. I ordered the forager, and I loved the cashews and cocoa nibs on top. Basik has a good array of options as well. 

The acai bowl itself was not really great - actual acai was my least favorite in SF, and the strawberries on top were bitter and gross and tasted very out of season. I took all the strawberries out of my bowl. Maybe Basik should consider figuring out how to use seasonal/fresh fruits for their $12 bowls. Not worth the hype or wait, other places are better.
author: Lauren G.

description:
Mmmm!!!

When the only items on the menu are acai bowls (and smoothies), you know they have good acai bowls. I personally think Basik Cafe has the best acai bowls in the city! The acai bowls come in two sizes - the difference between the small and large is pretty significant. If you ask me, I would just say, "supersize it!" For a couple more dollars, you can more than double your delicious acai bowl. A large is plenty enough for 2-3 people.

I've tried the Brasilian (classic acai blend, tangy and fruity), Islander (has hemp milk, so it's more creamy), and Puna (has spirulina powder, so has a greens/leafy hint). I'm not a huge fan of the nutty acai bowls, but they have a few blends on the menu that incorporate lots of nuts. There's something for everyone! : )

In addition to the acai bowl menu, they also have a smoothie menu. Most people come here for the acai bowls, so I'd stick with an acai bowl. I did recently try the Acai smoothie and it was underwhelming. It wasn't a very satisfying smoothie. The texture was more like a thick juice; it had a very watery consistency. 

The store is very clean and on the smaller size (there are 2 small tables and limited bar-style seats by the window). 

One thing to note is that they are very strict with their closing times. If they say they will close at 1PM, THEY WILL CLOSE at 1PM sharp. Even if you were waiting in line for 30 mins and you finally make it up to the ordering window - once it hits 1PM, they will turn you and everyone else behind you away. That actually happened to me... it's sad, but I respect that. Just something to keep in mind... : P


TL;DR
- best acai bowls in the city
- large size is best value
- very strict closing times; do not come around closing, especially if there is a line
- there is usually a line out the door
- they have smoothies, but they're just okay... stick with acai bowls imo
- limited indoor seating
- clean store/clean bathroom
author: Monica T.

description: Quality ingredients, small portions. One of the better acai places in SF almost comparable to places in Hawaii.
author: Fernilla S.

description: I'm sure Basik is terribly overpriced for what it is, but their Acai bowls are DIVINE and I would pay the price for it.  I'd have the Forager everyday if I could. Fan!
author: Christine A.

description: Amazing. Best acai bowl in SF, truly great bowl with so many options to add on. The portion size is great - enough for 2 meals (at least!). Between the acai, granola and fruit, its the best mix!
author: Grace P.

description:
So, this place moved in right around the corner from me, and I could not be more thrilled! I love all the bowls especially the 'Banyan' which has seemed to become my new addiction. I literally get one almost everyday.
When it's not packed in there, the bowls come out super fast and always with a smile and warmth from the staff. I like the fact that I can order from their 'leapset' app and my bowl is ready when I show up. What I don't like is that I have to wait in line to just pick up my order. If they could make a area for pick up orders my life would be complete. 
This place makes me want to surround myself with people from the big island. They are all so radical, easy going and even when it's packed in there none of them appear overwhelmed. 
Thank you Basik Cafe for adding a healthy staple in my everyday life, and for all those delicious bowls you have come up with. 

Bravo
author: Alex D.

description:
I've had acai bowls from several different smoothie shops and cafes on the West Coast. Basik is by far my favorite!!

The line gets long on the weekend, but it's well worth the wait. 

Yum!
author: Paloma A.

description: The Acai bowls are pretty pricey however the portion is big for one person. Didn't know which to get so I got the basic Brasilian bowl. It tasted amazing, and I would definitely come back again to try other bowls.
author: Michelle T.

description: Went in expecting acai bowls to be overhyped but boy was I pleasantly surprised. I ordered a small islander and it was the perfect morning pick me up. I want to eat these everyday until I go broke.
author: Emily S.

description: Refreshing and healthy smoothies and acai bowls. Prices are on the upper end however.  Only thing that kept me from giving them 5 stars.
author: Amy S.

description: I am a firm believer that the Bay Area has the best Acai Bowls! Basik's appearance was very cute and the menu was very accommodating! There was many options to add on or replace! The bowls are a little pricey, but you definitely get a bigger size than places such as Jamba Juice. I left 100% satisfied and cannot wait to come back.
author: Lauren H.

description:
Been craving for acai bowls lately, and I'm happy that they serve legit acai with real fresh ingredients in Polk St!

I can imagine myself eating this everyday, it's sooooo good :) I will definitely be back to try the other flavors. The Banyan and Islander are house favorites, but the Puna didn't disappoint as well.

Oh and don't be shy to get the large one! It feeds two people but if you're really hungry, you're basically good to go for the day! Talk about power breakfast
author: Jodie M.

description: I love coming here when I'm in the Polk-District.  I love their commitment of sharing healthy food such as Acai bowls with this community.  Let's be honest, most restaurant don't have access to healthy, delicious, and beneficial food for our only body we have.  The Acai bowls vary in two sizes and prices also depends on what types of super foods you want included in your Acai bowl.  I don't make $100,000 like most residence in San Francisco, but I never hesitate to spend money on food that is good for me because my health has no price.  Unfortunately, I also know many people who would like to join the healthy food movement can't afford to. It can be expensive to bring a family of 3 to Basik Cafe--looking at around $45. Nonetheless, I will be back for Acai bowls that are delicious and scrumptious.
author: Jo T.

description:
Listen, I don't think I've ever written a YELP review, but I just had to on this place. First off, let me tell you what's great about this place. I love the decor, the cleanliness, the fact they use organic and fresh ingredients, and the location. Once I saw it was open, my coworkers and I started visiting it every other day. I typically have good experiences with the staff. I have only tried one smoothie - the Wailea and for the most part, it's amazing (hence why it's the only drink I've tried.) There have been three or four times I've ordered it and received a different drink. I know this because the color and taste is different. Only knowing what the Wailea tastes like helps. Each time I spoke to the staff about it, they were some-what defensive, but always made the drink again. The second time making it--it's always right! Since I leave with the correct drink, I never complain. 

Today was a different experience. I ordered the Wailea and got the wrong drink. I told the guy at the register what was going on and he grabbed the owner. The owner is a bearded bald guy that wears flip flops and white tees. He listened to my concern and then showed me the receipt which shows I ordered a Wailea. I agreed and stated that the drink didn't taste like the Wailea I normally get from them. I explained that this had happened before and that each time they remake it, the drink is correct. Instead of calmly remaking the drink, refunding my money, or apologizing--he chose to tell me I was wrong, belittled me in front of customers, and outwardly showed frustration. 

I worked in hospitality/food service for over 10 years and I know that it can be hard to apologize and swallow your pride when you've made a mistake. This was worse than that. He told me that they didn't have measuring spoons and blamed it on one of the ingredients being too powerful. How can you expect to make the same drink over and over with no failure without measuring spoons? How can the consumer recommend a business and its product to someone else, without the guarantee it will be the same product for that future consumer? This blows my mind. 

To conclude, I was made another drink. It was not the Wailea.
author: Jessica R.

description: I crave their acai bowls ALL of the time. I could eat them for breakfast, lunch and dinner. The Brazilian bowl is my favorite, although sometimes I mix it up and order the Islander. The bowls are super fresh and filling, and the large is the perfect size for two people. The vibe is great, and the staff is super positive. There is usually a line, but definitely worth the wait. My only gripe is how early they close. I always crave an acai bowl on Sunday afternoon but they're always closed before I can get there! The bowls are also pretty pricey, but understandable given all of the fresh ingredients.
author: Regina L.

description: First had acai bowl in Palm Spring and have been looking for in ever since I came back to SF. My friend  introduced me to Basik Cafe and I'm in love with it. Love PUNA and FORAGER!!
author: Nuntanat R.

description:
My absolute favorite place for Acai bowls in the city. Whether I'm eating in or ordering through post mates, the bowls have always been fresh and delicious. I usually order the smaller size and it's quite filling, I'm a very petite girl so I can't imagine trying to finish the large. 

My two favorite are their regular Brazilian bowl and their Tropical bowl. Super fresh ingredients and you can tell they make everything to order in the back, their menu is very simple and easy to understand. The location is clean and very welcoming, I love introducing new people to try this spot, whether they're acai vets or newbies, everyone has been extremely pleased. 

My only gripe is their hours, I wish they stayed open later. As I am writing this review, I may or may not be drooling over the thought of having another bowl soon.
author: Mindy T.

description:
I went to Brazil in 2014 and that's where I fell in LOVE with Acai! To my surprise, there weren't that many places that sold Acai in the city at that time. It's getting more popular but none compare to the ones in Brazil or my next favorite Acai place - Backyard Bowls in Santa Barbara!

I'm so glad I found Basik Cafe! It's my go-to for an Acai bowl at home. I only wish that it was closer to me. The prices are a little steep but the large is massive! I always get the large because it's practically double the amount for only a couple bucks more! They're all so amazinggg I can't wait to go back!!!
author: Michelle L.

description: This is a little modern shop with various smoothies, acai bowls and coffee. I got the Brazilian bowl topped with banana, granola and honey. It was quite delicious and reminded me of bowls that I've gotten in Hawaii! It was the perfect morning treat. At $8 the cost was a little high for the small but at $12 the large is so gigantic, it would be well worth the price and easily about to feed 2 people!
author: Charlotte A.

description:
Trending.

Too much: http://www.tkryer.com/#!Have-we-stretched-the-bounds-of-yoga-pants-too-far-/c1ulg/1

Not enough: http://insidescoopsf.sfgate.com/blog/2015/02/09/basik-cafe-introduces-acai-bowls-to-san-franciscos-polk-street/

Basik brought the two trends together. Yoga pants and acai were everywhere. Not sure about the former. Absolutely sure of the latter.

Kilauea bowl with acai, granola, raspberries, strawberries, goji berries, bee pollen and honey was sweet and delicious. Reasonable $14 for a large feeds three. 

Kona smoothie with more acai, more strawberries, banana, spirulina, ginger, lime and hemp mylk was not as sweet but still delicious. Fair $7 for a small.

Prepare for a small space with a long line. There are tables inside but seems to be more grab and go. Acai was ours within five minutes of ordering.

These two should (for better or worse) keep trending.
author: Jason B.

description: The Bowls are your best bet -- smoothies are either too sugary or tasteless.  Biggest issue though is that they have a blatant disregard for their line.  The cashier will chat people up and walk away from the register while 20+ stand in line waiting.  Unless you're desperate or have nothing better to do with your time, go elsewhere.
author: Sharon G.

description:
My boyfriend and I wandered in here out of curiosity. The atmosphere is very jungle food bar. 

The girl who greeted us was very friendly and informed us that we they had only opened one minute before, making us their first guinea pigs (read: customers). 

We ordered the Forager bowl and the Puna bowl. The bowls were large, full of super fresh ingredients, and delicious! 

This place is definitely worth a visit - even if you don't live in the area (I know we will be back). 

Final verdict: amaze-bowls! 
(yes, I just did that)
author: Wil M.

description:
PSA: Their store was broken into on Saturday (4/25) so they were closed temporarily as of Sunday (4/26) morning as they handled the damage. Hopefully they will be back soon - so excited to try their acai bowls!  

Tip: 
+Call before heading over to see if they're up and running!
author: Anu P.

description: I was trying to get everyone, I was trying tell everyone about the acai bowl we ate for breakfast in Hawaii. This place is even better than Hawaii's. I'm happy this place is here in our neighborhood.
author: Bebe L.

description: Is everyone high? Great product, but the employees always seems to be in their own world every time I come in here. The line out the door isn't because it's that great, it's because they're running the most inefficient assembly line I've ever seen! They guy or gal who takes the order is also delivering orders, busing tables, or playing with their cell phone. There are always two or three people in the back making the bowls and smoothies, but most of the time they're just staring off in a another dimension with a banana in their hand. Don't come here hangry, or in a rush, or looking for something reasonably priced. At the prices they charge, the produce should be organic. With that said, their bowls and smoothies are amazing, next time I'm just need to ask them to add some of whatever they're smoking on top.
author: Maya B.

description:
Weekdays there is usually no line, but on the weekends there is often a line, especially in the morning.  I have tried a few of their acai bowls and they're all delicious.  Lots of fresh fruit and other yummy ingredients.  I have yet to try their smoothies, but they also look good.  Yes, a bit expensive, but acai is pricey!  

The staff is super nice and friendly.  They make each bowl individually as you order and bring it as it is ready.  There are some tables to sit and eat/drink as well.
author: Christina C.

description:
SO GOOD. 

As an Acai Bowl virgin, I'm glad Basik Cafe was my first time. 

Only qualm was that it was a too pricey, but I guess that's what I guess for visiting SF. 

(Only had the Banyan (amazing!), just can't speak to the other menu options.
author: Kimmi V.

description:
I WILL NEVER RETURN. The acai is sub par, their hours are unreliable, and they obviously don't know how to run a business because they always run out and their stated hours have them closed during what should be peak hours. Plus, they're impolite.

This is my only yelp review ever - that's how serious this is. Thanks.
author: Sheela S.

description:
Really, really stupid to turn away people that have been waiting in line for 15+ minutes because you have to restock. I get that restocking is a need but then cut off the line at the right time instead of alienating your customers. Totally mindless business move. Won't be coming back.

Or, be like every other restaurant in the world and have someone restocking and prepping throughout the day versus close at the hottest lunch hour. Really dumb.

Update: My girlfriend persuades me to go back today and guess what, they are "sold out"! Hahahah Guys, learn how to run a business. You sell one freaking product. Have enough stocked where you don't sell out. What a joke.
author: J P.

description: Line moves quickly, everything I've tried tastes delicious although they all start to taste the same. Forager is my favorite. Price is up there so it's more of a treat to come here than a routine
author: Sophie W.

description: Best Acai Bowl in SF :) definitely worth the wait every time!
author: Jen G.

description:
Not a good way to run a business. Understandable that you may stop serving at 12 to restock,however you should come to the end of the line where people were waiting prior to your cut off time. To just randomly pick a cut off spot in a line is not the way to do it.
I've been to plenty of restaurants where they stop serving at a certain time but would never say to customer they couldn't place an order once seated.
I'm sure there are plenty of other places in the area that you could find acai bowls and smoothies.
Won't be revisiting this establishment
author: L M.

description: I was really excited to try this place especially since it's so popular in Hawaii, but my expectations were too high because the acai bowl was just average to me. I got the "Banyan" which seems to be one of their most popular bowls. The acai was a bit watered down and did not have the real taste of acai berries compared to Blue Hawaii Cafe. If you've tried both, you can definitely tell the difference in terms of texture and taste. I've also tried Bebebar which is another popular acai place in the city and would say Basik is a bit better. Overall, I'm glad I tried it but definitely recommend trying Blue Hawaii Cafe if you haven't already!
author: Julia H.

description: This place is amazing! I always get the banyan bowl and I am obsessed with it! The people are friendly and it usually doesn't take too long! The only thing that isn't ideal is that the price is only 3 dollars more for the large but it's so much bigger! It's like a medium size would be so great the large is just so big but for the price is makes more sense to order it!
author: Jazlyn H.

description: Gotta love the acai bowl.  Unknowingly had been to the one in Kona and didn't realize they were connected.  Food is delicious and size is huge.  The shape of the cup is somewhat tough to eat out of - would prefer more of a bowl so that each bite is more diverse.  But definitely worth the wait in the line out front, especially if you're craving it.  Food comes out very quickly.
author: Sam E.

description: Always really delicious and everyone is really nice and chill. The interior is cool, a little industrial polished look. I love the bananas on top, they are so fluffy and a perfect topping. If you go on Sundays around 10-11a there wasn't much of a wait, but it could have been a fluke lol
author: Izzles A.

description: Cute little shop located in Nob Hill. The acai bowls are great light breakfast option or a refreshing little pick me up on a hot summer afternoon. The menu is limited but I'm sure you can build your own! I've had their banyan, islander and a dawn special they had. I love the addition of bee pollen, hemp hearts and real honey on top. The only thing is it's a little pricey for the smaller size ($11). Basik would be an occasional treat I would give to myself but it would not be something I would eat weekly.
author: Tami T.

description: This is our favorite acai bowl place in the city and we've tried a lot.  Lines can be long but move pretty quickly. We try to get there close to opening in Sunday, and never have a problem getting a place to sit.
author: Barrie S.

description:
Basik is a wonderful addition to the family of acai bowl shops within San Francisco. Conveniently placed by all the hustle and bustle of Polk st, it's definitely a wonderful after workout treat or good weekend spot when frolicking around town with friends.

The diversity in toppings is the best in the city, and the authentic Hawaiian vibes bring good vibes to the interior.

I would give this place a shot! You won't regret it!
author: Meaghan H.

description:
I've been waiting for Basik to open since November 2013 when I found out they had signed a lease for SF. I emailed them, followed them on instagram, and pretty much made sure I would know as soon as their SF store opens. Basik Acai in Kona was one of my favorite places on the Big Island so I would go there at least 2 times every time I visited. I haven't had an acai bowl in California that tasted like the one in Kona, so needless to say, I was extremely excited for this and had high expectations. 

I tried the puna bowl, kilaueau bowl, and banyan bowl with two friends. Perhaps because the girl behind the counter is still new and hasn't perfected proportions needed to make the acai base, but the acai base for our 3 bowls had varying textures.  It was very apparent that the puna bowl was the iciest since there were ice crystals...
The kilaueau bowl tasted extremely diluted and barely had acai taste to it. The banyan bowl had more flavor since the peanut butter thickened the acai base and gave it more taste. The fresh fruit toppings and granola on all the bowls were the best part!  

Overall I was very disappointed in the lack of flavor in the acai base. I'll probably give Basik Cafe another chance after a couple of months.
author: Cindy L.

description:
Wait really?

2 1/2 stars guys.

I'll give plus points to fresh ingredients, but that's kind of table stakes when I'm paying $11 for a bowl. To me, the ratios were totally off - 1/3 acai base, 1/3 banana, 1/3 granola (got the banyan bowl). The granola was so abundant that it soaked up all the sorbet and I couldn't appreciate a virgin bite of acai base. The banana was underripe and detracted from the flavors instead of enhancing, as underripe bananas will do. And when I asked to do half and half banana and strawberry instead of all banana, I got the longest pause followed by response of "well.. We only use half a banana in there so if we cut that in half you'd get like two slices". So what do you do then for all the other bowls where it is a banana strawberry mix?? In any case, for those wondering, I had 10-15 solid fat slices of underripe banana in my bowl.

Given all the glowing reviews I will shell out another 11 bucks to give Basik a second shot and happily update my review if  it turns out I simply got an off bowl. Until then I feel like there should at least be a review on here that reflects a not-so-perfect experience.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
I checked out Basik Cafe yesterday. They're coffee is not good (one of the worst I've ever had) BUT their bowls were a pleasant surprise. The bowls are like froyo with granola and other goodies. 

Verdict:
Come back for a smoothie/bowl but skip the coffee. I would give them 1 star because they have cafe in their name and have bad bad coffee, but the bowls are good.
author: Marlyn F.

description:
Basik is fantastic! One of my favorite Acai bowls east oh the Islands! Location is great and is always busy.

The only reason why I took a start off was because the line is always so long (which isn't really there fault), and it is a little expensive. $14 for a large bowl seems pricey but it does taste amazing.
author: Justin P.

description:
